Dublin Core:Description: The mountebank^^ from whom Tito Melema rescues Tessa. He performs the mock marriage ceremony for Tessa and Tito^^ and later^^ disguised as a contadina^^ plays on the doctor^^ Maestro Tacco^^ the trick described in the chapter "The Florentine Joke".

Dublin Core:Description: Workman engaged in decoration the ceiling of the saloon at Cheverel Manor.

Dublin Core:Title: Bath (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Bath (Real)^^The town to which Captain Wybrow goes to court Miss Assher. A noted English watering-place in Somerset^^ fashionable in the eighteenth century.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Che Faro Senza Euridice (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Sir Christopher Cheverel's favourite airs^^ which Caterina sings to him. A song from Gluck's opera Orfeo^^ act 3.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: "Ho Perduto Il Bel Sembiante" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of the songs which Caterina sings to Sir Christopher Cheverel. In the first edition of Mr. Gilfil George Eliot describes this song as being from Gluck's Orfeo^^ but in the revised edition she changed the text to read: "Sir Christopher's favorite airs^^ by Gluck and Paisiello." It is by Giovanni Paisiello (1741-1816)^^ and^^ when Caterina sang it^^ was one of the new songs of the day^^ as it had been sung two years before^^ in 1786^^ at Naples^^ by the popular prima donna^^ Anna Morichelli. It is from Paisiello's cantata Amor vendicato^^ first presented at Naples^^ 30th June^^ 1786. That cantata seems to have been called sometimes Dafne ed Alceo^^ from its principal characters.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: "Roy's Wife of Aldivalloch" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: Song sung by Mr. Bates^^ the gardener. A favourite Scottish song^^ written near the end of the eighteenth century by Mrs. Elizabeth Grant^^ of Carron.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Callam
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Callam^^Village.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Cheverel Manor
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Cheverel Manor^^Home of Sir Christopher and Lady Cheverel^^ which Sir Christopher rebuilds in the Gothic style. "The castellated house of grey-tinted stone^^ with the flickering sunbeams sending dashes of golden light across the many-shaped panes in the mullioned windows^^ and a great beech leaning athwart one of the flanking towers^^ and breaking^^ with its dark flattened boughts^^ the too formal symmetry of the front; the broad gravel-walk winding on the right^^ by a row of tall pines^^ alongside the pool--on the left branching out among selling grassy mounds^^ surmounted by clumps of trees^^ where the red trunk of the Scotch fir glows in the descending sunlight against the bright green of limes and acacias." The original of Cheverel Manor was Arbury Hall^^ the seat of the Newdigate family near Nuneaton^^ which was rebuilt in the Gothic style by Sir Roger Newdigate just as Cheverel Manor was rebuilt by Sir Christopher. George Eliot was frequently at Arbury during her childhood (See Newdigate^^ The Cheverels^^ passim; Bartholomew^^ Literary and Historical Atlas^^ p. 135.)
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Description: Crowspot Cottage^^A cottage on the Cheverel estate.

Dublin Core:Title: Knebley Church
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Knebley Church^^Church where Mr. Gilfil officiates on Sunday afternoons. "A wonderful little church . . . with a checkered pavement which had once rung to the iron tread of military monks^^ with coats of arms in clusters on the lofty roof^^ marble warriors and their wives without noses occupying a large proportion of the area^^ and the twelve apostles^^ with their heads very much on one side^^ holding didactic ribbons^^ painted in fresco on the walls." The original of Knebley Church was Astley Church^^ a mile west of Arbury Park. (See Andrews^^ Bygone Warwickshire^^ p. 271; Parkinson^^ Scenes^^ pp. 12^^ 52.)
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Cheverel^^ Sir Anthony
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An imposing ancestor of Sir Christopher's^^ the renovator of the family splendour in the reign of Charles II. The original of Sir Anthony Cheverel was Sir Richard Newdegate^^ first baronet.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Cheverel^^ Sir Christopher
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The proud^^ strong-willed^^ but kind-hearted^^ owner of Cheverel Manor. "As fine a specimen of the old English gentleman as could well have been found in those venerable days of cocked-hats and pigtails. His dark eyes sparkled under projecting brows^^ made more prominent by bushy grizzled eyebrows; but any apprehension of severity excited by these penetrating eyes^^ and by a somewhat aquiline nose^^ was allayed by the good-natured lines about the mouth^^ which retained all its teeth and its vigour of expression in spite of sixty winters. The forehead sloped a little from the projecting brows^^ and its peaked outline was made conspicuous by the arrangement of the profusely powdered hair^^ drawn backward and gathered into a pigtail." His pride and ambition are centred in his beautiful house^^ which he is rebuilding^^ and in his nephew and heir^^ Captain Wybrow^^ whose marriage to Miss Assher he uses every effort to further. He is fond also of his protegee^^ Caterina Sarti^^ and^^ quite blind to her passion for Captain Wybrow^^ is anxious to have her marry Mr. Gilfil^^ his ward. He is deeply affected by the death of his nephew and Caterina's unhappiness. The original of Sir Christopher was Sir Roger Newdigate^^ fifth baronet. (See Newdigate^^ The Cheverels^^ pp. 229-31; Stephen^^ George Eliot^^ pp. 56-7.)
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Cheverl^^ Henrietta^^ Lady
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Sir Christopher's stately wife; an unsympathetic^^ awe-inspiring but kind woman. "She is tall^^ and looks the taller because her powdered hair is turned backward over a toupee^^ and surmounted by lace and ribbons. She is nearly fifty^^ but her complexion is still fresh and beautiful^^ with the beauty of an auburn blonde; her proud pouting lips^^ and her head thrown a little backward as she walks^^ give an expression of hauteur which is not contradicted by the cold grey eye. The tucked-in kerchief^^ rising full over the low tight bodice of her blue dress^^ sets off the majestic form of her bust^^ and she treads the lawn as if she were one of Sir Joshua Reynolds's stately ladies^^ who had suddenly stepped from her frame to enjoy the evening cooL" "Lady Cheverel^^ though not very tender-hearted^^ still less sentimental^^ was essentially kind^^ and liked to dispense benefits like a goddess^^ who looks down benignly on the halt^^ the maimed^^ and the blind that approach her shrine." The original of Lady Cheverel was Hester Margaretta (Mundy)^^ Lady Newdigate^^ Sir Roger Newdigate's second wife. (See Newdigate^^ The Cheverels^^ p. 229.)
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Crichley^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The old rector of Cumbermoor.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Ford^^ Old "Mester"
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "A true Staffordshire patriarch."
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Fripp^^ Dame
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A dirty old woman to whom Mr. Gilfil was kind.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Gilfil^^ Rev. Maynard
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Sir Christopher Cheverel's ward and chaplain^^ later vicar of Shepperton and Knebley; a man greatly beloved by his parishioners. " The Vicar did not shine in the more spiritual functions of his office; and indeed^^ the utmost I can say for him in this respect is^^ that he performed those functions with undeviating attention to brevity and despatch. He had a large heap of short sermons^^ rather yellow and worn at the edges^^ from which he took two every Sunday^^ securing perfect impartiality in the selection by taking them as they came without reference to topics; and having preached one of these sermons at Shepperton in the morning^^ he mounted his horse and rode hastily with the other in his pocket to Knebley^^ where he officiated in a wonderful little church .... Here^^ in an absence of mind to which he was prone^^ Mr. Gillil would sometimes forget to take off his spurs before putting on his surplice^^ and only become aware of the omission by feeling something mysteriously tugging at the skirts of that garment as he stepped into the reading-desk." "The dear old Vicar^^ though he had something of the knotted whimsical character of the poor lopped oak^^ had yet been sketched out by nature as a noble tree. The heart of him was sound^^ the grain was of the finest^^ and in the grey-haired man who filled his pocket with sugar-plums for the little children^^ whose most biting words were directed against the evil-doing of the rich man^^ and who^^ with all his social pipes and slipshod talk^^ never sank below the highest level of his parishioners' respect^^ there was the main trunk of the same brave^^ faithful^^ tender nature that had poured out the finest^^ freshest forces of its life-current in a first and only love—the love of Tina." All through his youth he loves the little Italian^^ Caterina^^ and tries to watch over her during her unhappy love affair with the worthless Captain Wybrow. After she partially recovers from the shock of Captain Wybrow's death he marries her^^ and has a few months of great happiness as her husband. When she dies^^ that side of his life is closed forever^^ and he lives a solitary life among his parishioners^^ all of whom admire and respect him greatly. The Reverend Bernard Gilpin Ebdell^^ who married Sally Shilton ("Caterina")^^ was the original of Maynard Gilfil. It has been suggested that some touches in his character are taken from the Reverend Henry Hake^^ vicar of Chilvers Coton from 1844- 1859. (See Andrews^^ Bygone Warwickshire^^ p. 271 ; Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ pp. 15^^ 33 ; also article by George Morley in Gentleman's Magazine^^ n.s.^^ vol. 45^^ p. 583.) Bernard Gilpin Ebdell^^ vicar of Chilvers Coton^^ was the clergyman who^^ in 1819^^ baptized Mary Ann Evans. He was vicar 1786-1828.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Parrot^^ Bessie
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A flaxen-headed little girl.
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Patten^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A rich old lay of Shepperton^^ tenant of Cross Farm. "Mrs. Patten^^ a childless old lady^^ who had got rich chiefly by the negative process of spending nothing . . . She is a pretty little old woman of eighty^^ with a close cap and tiny flat white curls round her face^^ as natty and unsoiled and invariable as the waxen image of a little old lady under a glass-case; once a lady's-maid^^ and married for her beauty. She used to adore her husband^^ and now she adores her money^^ cherishing a quiet blood-relation's hatred for her niece^^ Janet Gibbs^^ who^^ she knows^^ expects a large legacy^^ and whom she is determined to disappoint." The original of Mrs. Patten is said to have been a Mrs. Hutchings or Hutchins. (Manuscript information; also Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ p. 14.)
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Sarti^^ Caterina^^ called Tina
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An affectionate and beautiful Italian girl with a fine voice^^ who is brought up by Sir Christopher and Lady Cheverel. "You are at once arrested by her large dark eyes^^ which^^ in their inexpressive unconscious beauty^^ resemble the eyes of a fawn; and it is only by an effort of attention that you notice the absence of bloom on her young cheek^^ and the southern yellowish tint of her small neck and face^^ rising above the little black lace kerchief which prevents the too immediate comparison of her skin with her white muslin gown. Her large eyes seem all the more striking because the dark hair is gathered away from her face^^ under a little cap set at the top of her head^^ with a cherry colored bow on one side. "With one exception^^ her only talent lay in loving ; and there^^ it is probable^^ the most astronomical of women could not have surpassed her. Orphan and protegee though she was^^ this supreme talent of hers found plenty of exercise at Cheverel Manor . . . the one other exceptional talent^^ you already guess^^ was music." "Said Mr. Bates^^ 'for she hasn't the cut of a gell as must work for her bread; she's as nesh an' dilicate as a paichblossom—welly laike a linnet^^ wi' on'y joost body anoof to hold her voice.' " She falls in love with the handsome unscrupulous Captain Wybrow^^ and when he heartlessly forsakes her for Miss Assher^^ she is maddened by jealousy. She goes to meet him in the Rookery^^ thinking that she will kill him. When she reaches the Rookery she finds him dead. Many months later^^ when she has partially recovered from the shock^^ her affectionate heart leads her to marry Mr. Gilfil^^ her faithful lover^^ but she lives only a few months after their marriage. The prototype of Caterina was Sally Shilton^^ a young girl with a beautiful voice who has brought up and educated by Lady Newdigate ("Lady Cheverel"). Sally Shilton married Bernard Gilpin Ebdell (" Maynard Gilfil ") but did not die at an early age^^ as did Caterina. (See Newdigate^^ The Cheverels^^ pp. 75^^ 220^^ 228.)
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Wybrow^^ Captain Anthony
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Sir Christopher Cheverel's nephew and heir; a handsome^^ irreproachable young dandy^^ incapable of any strong emotion. "If this young man had been less elegant in his person^^ he would have been remarked for the elegance of his dress. But the perfections of his slim^^ well-proportioned figure were so striking that no one but a tailor could notice the perfections of his velvet coat; and his small white hands^^ with their blue veins and taper fingers^^ quite eclipsed the beauty of his lace ruffles. The face^^ however—it was difficult to say why—was certainly not pleasing. Nothing could be more delicate than the blond complexion—its bloom set off by the powdered hair—than the veined overhanging eyelids^^ which gave an indolent expression to the hazel eyes ; nothing more finely cut than the transparent nostril and the short upper-lip. Perhaps the chin nd lower jaw were too small for an irreproachable profile^^ but the defect was on the side of that delicacy and finesse which was the distinctive characteristic of the whole person^^ and which was carried out in the clear brown arch of the eyebrows^^ and the marble smoothness of the sloping forehead." He deliberately wins the love of Caterina^^ his uncle's penniless protegee^^ without intending to marry her. In response to his uncle's wishes he becomes engaged to the beauty^^ Miss Assher^^ and gives no thought to the suffering he causes Caterina. When her jealousy annoys him^^ his weak heart causes his death. Charles Parker^^ nephew and heir of Sir Roger Newdigate ("Sir Christopher Cheverel") was^^ in the matter of his personal appearance^^ his relation to a rich and childless uncle and his sudden death^^ the original of Captain Wybrow. Captain Wybrow's love affair with Caterina is purely fictitious^^ however^^ as Sally Shilton ("Caterina") was only a child at the time of Charles Parker's marriage to Miss Anstruther ("Miss Assher"). (See Newdigate^^ The Cheverels^^ p. 228.)
Dublin Core:Source: Mr. Gilfil's Love Story^^ Scenes of Clerical Life

Dublin Core:Title: Avignon (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Avignon (Real)^^The French city where Lydgate found Madame Laure when he followed her from Paris. A picturesque town on the Rhone^^ about 400 miles south of Paris.

Dublin Core:Title: Boulogne (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Boulogne (Real)^^Place where Raffles had known Will Ladislaw's father. Boulogne^^ in the departement of Pas-de-Calais^^ a French seaport on the English Channel.

Dublin Core:Title: Brasenose (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Brasenose (Real)^^The college to which Mr. Casaubon's dreaded critic^^ Mr. Carp^^ belongs. A college at Oxford^^ founded 1509 by William Smith^^ Bishop of Lincoln^^ and Sir Richard Sutton.

Dublin Core:Title: Campagna (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Campagna (Real)^^One of Dorothea Brooke's favourite drives while she was in Rome. A large plain surrounding Rome which offers opportunity for many excursions.

Dublin Core:Title: Cheltenham (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Cheltenham (Real)^^A fashionable resort and watering-place in Gloucestershire^^ seven miles north-east of Gloucester.

Dublin Core:Title: College of Physicians (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: College of Physicians (Real)^^The Royal College of Physicians^^ London.

Dublin Core:Title: East Retford (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: East Retford (Real)^^A place where there was much bribery at elections. In 1828^^ one year before the time of Middlemarch^^ the borough of East Retford in Nottinghamshire was disenfranchised for repeated and incurable bribery.

Dublin Core:Title: Edinburgh (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Edinburgh (Real)^^One of the places where Lydgate had carried on his medical studies. At the time of Middlemarch^^ in the early nineteenth century^^ Edinburgh was an important centre of medical study^^ which was carried on both at the University and in private medical classes.

Dublin Core:Title: Freiberg (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Freiberg (Real)^^A town where Dorothea Brooke enjoyed hearing the famous organ^^ on her way home from Lausanne. Freiburg^^ or Fribourg^^ in Switzerland; the organ in the cathedral is one of the largest and finest in Europe.

Dublin Core:Title: Heidelberg (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Heidelberg (Real)^^The German university where Will Ladislaw had studied. A university town in Baden^^ the seat of the oldest university in Germany.

Dublin Core:Title: Highbury (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Highbury (Real)^^Location of the dissenting church in which Mr. Bulstrode had been a power when he lived in London. The district of Highbury^^ north of Islington^^ which forms a suburb of London.

Dublin Core:Title: Lausanne (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Lausanne (Real)^^Town where Dorothea and Celia Brooke had finished their education^^ in a Swiss family. Lausanne^^ near Lake Geneva^^ the capital of the Canton of Vaud^^ in Switzerland.

Dublin Core:Title: Porte Saint Martin (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Porte Saint Martin (Real)^^The theatre in Paris where Madame Laure was acting when Lydgate was in love with her. An old well-known theatre in Paris.

Dublin Core:Title: Rugby (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Rugby (Real)^^The school to which Mr. Casaubon had sent Will Ladislaw. Rugby School^^ a famous English public school at Rugby^^ founded in 1567 by Lawrence Sheriffe^^ citizen and grocer^^ of London.

Dublin Core:Title: St. Peter's^^ Rome (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: St. Peter's^^ Rome (Real)^^One of the places which Dorothea and Mr. Casaubon visit on their honeymoon. St. Peter's (San Pietro in Vaticano)^^ the great Cathedral in Rome.

Dublin Core:Title: Sistina^^ Via (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Sistina^^ Via (Real)^^The street in Rome where Mr. and Mrs. Casaubon stay on their wedding trip. A broad street beginning at the top of the Scala di Spagna and running southeast.

Dublin Core:Title: Vatican (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Vatican (Real)^^Museum and Library which the Casaubons visit in Rome. The Vatican Palace^^ the residence of the popes and headquarters of the Papacy^^ contains many collections^^ including the collection of antiquities which Mrs. Casaubon visited^^ and a great library especially rich in manuscripts^^ where Mr. Casaubon carried on his researches.

Dublin Core:Title: "Batti^^ Batti" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of the songs which Rosamond Vincy sings. "Batti batti^^ o bel Masetto^^" an aria by Mozart.

Dublin Core:Title: "Black-Eyed Susan" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of the songs which Rosamond Vincy sings. A song composed by Richard Leveridge (c. 1670-1758)^^ said to have been arranged by him from a still older melody.

Dublin Core:Title: "Cherry Ripe" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: Song which Fred Vincy strums on the piano. The words of the song are by Herrick^^ the music by Charles E. Horn.

Dublin Core:Title: Finsbury (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: Finsbury (Real)

Dublin Core:Title: "Flow on^^ Thou Shining River" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: A song which Rosamond Vincy sings to Mr. Featherstone.

Dublin Core:Title: Haydn's Canzonets (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: Songs by Franz Joseph Haydn (1732-1809).

Dublin Core:Title: Home^^ Sweet Home (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: A song which Rosamond Vincy sings to Peter Featherstone^^ although she detests it. This well known song by John Howard Payne^^ from his opera "Clari^^ or the Maid of Milan" which was first produced in 1823^^ was a comparatively new song when Rosamond Vincy sang it. The music is by Sir Henry Bishop.

Dublin Core:Title: "I've Been Roaming" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of the songs sung by Rosamond Vincy. The words of this songs were written by George Darley (1795-1846)^^ poet^^ critic^^ and mathematician^^ and were published in 1826 under his pseudonym of Guy Penseval in his Labours of Idleness. The music is by C. E. Horn.

Dublin Core:Title: "Lancet" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: A medical periodical^^ the attitude of which on the coronership is discussed by the medical men in Middlemarch. The Lancet^^ London^^ founded 1823 by Thomas Wakley.

Dublin Core:Title: "Last Rose of Summer" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: A well-known song^^ with words by Thomas Moore^^ first published 1813^^ in his Irish Melodies; the air is altered from an older one called the "Groves of Blarney".

Dublin Core:Title: "Lungi dal Cara Bene" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: Music which Will Ladislaw and Mrs. Lydgate are playing when Dorothea interrupts them. A cavatina^^ by Giuseppe Sarti (1729-1802).

Dublin Core:Title: Parliamentary Candidate Society (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: A society "instituted to support reform by promoting the return of fit and proper members to Parliament"^^ active at the time of the Reform Bill.

Dublin Core:Title: "Voi^^ Che Sapete" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of the songs which Rosamond Vincy sings. By Mozart.

Dublin Core:Title: "When First I Saw Thy Face" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: A song which Will Ladislaw hums. "Since first I saw your face^^" an old song^^ with music by Thomas Ford^^ dating from 1607^^ which has retained its popularity during three centuries.

Dublin Core:Title: "Ye Banks and Braes" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: An air which Fred Vincy practices on his flute. "Ye banks and braes o' bonnie Doone^^" a song with words by Robert Burns set to an older tune of uncertain origin.

Dublin Core:Title: Bilkley
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Bilkley^^A town forty miles from Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Brassing
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Brassing^^Town near Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Bride Street
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Bride Street^^An insignificant street in Middlemarch^^ where the rooms are like cages.

Dublin Core:Title: Chalky Flats
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Chalky Flats^^Place where Mrs. Cranch resides.

Dublin Core:Title: Churchyard Lane
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Churchyard Lane^^Street in Middlmarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Crabsley
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Crabsley^^Town near Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Featherstone's Alms-Houses
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Featherstone's Alms-Houses^^Alms-houses for old men^^ for the erection of which Peter Featherstone bequeaths the residue of his property^^ after leaving his land to Joshua Rigg.

Dublin Core:Title: Freeman's End
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Freeman's End^^A picturesque but sadly neglected framhouse belonging to Mr. Brooke^^ and inhabited by the Dagleys.

Dublin Core:Title: Freshitt
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Freshitt^^Parish near Middlemarch^^ where Sir James Chettam lives.

Dublin Core:Title: Freshitt Hall
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Freshitt Hall^^Home of Sir James Chettam.

Dublin Core:Title: Frick
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Frick^^Hamlet in Lowick^^ where public opinion is against railways.

Dublin Core:Title: Halsell Common
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Halsell Common^^A piece of ground crossed by Will Ladislaw on his way to and from Lowick.

Dublin Core:Title: Halsell Wood
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Halsell Wood^^A wood near Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Houndsley
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Houndsley^^A town near Middlemarch where a horse fair is held^^ and where Fred Vincy makes an ill-judged purchase of a horse.

Dublin Core:Title: Ilsely
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Ilsely^^A town near Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Infirmary
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Infirmary^^The old hospital in Middlemarch; Mr. Tyke and Mr. Farebrother are both candidates for its chaplaincy^^ and Mr. Tyke is elected because Dr. Lydgate votes for him as Bulstrode's candidate.

Dublin Core:Title: Loamshire
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Loamshire^^The county in which Middlemarch is situated.

Dublin Core:Title: Finsbury
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Finsbury

Dublin Core:Title: Highbury
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Highbury

Dublin Core:Title: London Road
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: London Road^^"That pleasant issue from Middlemarch called London Road^^ which was also the road to the New Hospital."

Dublin Core:Title: Lowick
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Lowick^^Parish near Middlemarch. The parish of Lowick in Middlemarch is imaginary^^ though its name is real. When George Eliot chose the name she did not remember that there was any place of the name in England^^ but there are actually three parishes named Lowick^^ one of them in a Midland county. (See Cross^^ George Eliot's Life^^ vol. 3^^ p. 212.)

Dublin Core:Title: Lowick Church
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Lowick Church^^The church of which first Mr. Casaubon^^ and later Mr. Farebrother^^ is rector.

Dublin Core:Title: Lowick Gate
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Lowick Gate^^Street in Middlemarch where the Vincys live.

Dublin Core:Title: Lowick Manor
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Lowick Manor^^The residence of Mr. Casaubon and Dorothea. "It had a small park^^ with a fine old oak here and there^^ and an avenue of limes toward the south-west front^^ with a sunk fence between park and pleasure ground^^ so that from the drawingroom windows the glance swept uninterruptedly along a slope of greensward till the limes ended in a level of corn and pastures^^ which often seemed to melt into a lake under the setting sun . . . The building^^ of greenish stone^^ was in the old English style^^ not ugly^^ but small-windowed and melancholylooking ; the sort of house that must have children^^ many flowers^^ open windows^^ and little vistas of bright things^^ to make it seem a joyous home."

Dublin Core:Title: Lowick Parsonage
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Lowick Parsonage^^The home of the Farebrother family after Mrs. Casaubon gives the Lowick living to Mr. Farebrother.

Dublin Core:Title: Melspring
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Melspring^^Town.

Dublin Core:Title: Middlemarch
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Middlemarch^^A provincial town^^ the principal scene fo the novel^^ Middlemarch. eorge Eliot's impressions of her residence in Coventry provide the original for the picture of "Middlemarch"^^ although the picture is not developed with the detail shown in the portrait of Nuneaton as "Milby". (See Stephen^^ George Eliot^^ p. 34^^ 174; also his article on George Eliot in the Dictionary of National Biography.) One of the recognitions of George Eliot's connexion with Coventry is the decision to name all new streets opened in the Radford Garden suburbs (a region which was once one of her favourite walks) from her novels^^ and of the two streets^^ opened by 1922^^ one is "Middlemarch Road" and the other "Lydgate Road". Coventry has also a "George Eliot Road".

Dublin Core:Title: New Fever Hospital
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: New Fever Hospital^^The new hospital in Middlemarch which Mr. Bulstrode establishes and largely maintains^^ putting Dr. Lydgate in charge of the work.

Dublin Core:Title: North Quay
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: North Quay^^Place where Joshua Rigg plans to set up his money-changer's shop.

Dublin Core:Title: Omnibus College
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Omnibus College^^Fred Vincy's college.

Dublin Core:Title: Parley Street
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Parley Street^^Street in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Quillingham
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Quillingham^^Home of Sir Godwin Lydgate^^ where Lydgate and Rosamond go on their honeymoon.

Dublin Core:Title: Riverston
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Riverston^^Town near Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: St. Botolph's
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: St. Botolph's^^Mr. Farebrother's church^^ the oldest church in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: St. Peter's
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: St. Peter's^^Mr. Thesiger's church in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: St. Peter's Place
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: St. Peter's Place

Dublin Core:Title: Shrubs^^ The
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Shrubs^^ The^^Mr. Bulstrode's residence in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Slaughter Lane
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Slaughter Lane^^Street in Middlemarch where the "Tankard" is located.

Dublin Core:Title: Stone Court
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Stone Court^^Farm and residence of Peter Featherstone. "The house was already visible^^ looking as if it had been arrested in its growth toward a stone mansion by an unexpected budding of farm buildings on its left flank^^ which had hindered it from becoming anything more than the substantial dwelling of a gentleman farmer. It was not the less agreeable an object in the distance for the cluster of pinnacled corn ricks which balanced the fine row of walnuts on the right." After leading Fred Vincy to expect this property^^ old Featherstone leaves it to his illegitimate son^^ Rigg Featherstone. When the latter parts with it to Mr. Bulstrode^^ Fred Vincy and Mary Garth move into it and Fred gradually becomes owner of the stock and furniture.

Dublin Core:Title: Three Crofts
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Three Crofts^^Part of Peter Featherstone's property.

Dublin Core:Title: Tipton
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Tipton^^The parish near Middlemarch where Mr. Brooke lives.

Dublin Core:Title: Tipton Grange
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Tipton Grange^^Home of Mr. Brooke^^ where Dorothea and Celia Brooke live until they are married.

Dublin Core:Title: Yew-Tree Walk
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Yew-Tree Walk^^Mr. Casaubon's favourite walk in the grounds of Lowick Manor; it is in a little summer house near this walk that Dorothea finds him dead. A Yew-tree walk in the garden of Griff House^^ George Eliot's early home^^ served as the original of the Yew-tree walk at Lowick Manor^^ and a round stone table^^ now preserved at Bedworth Rectory^^ the home of the Reverend Frederic R. Evans (George Eliot's nephew) is pointed out as the original of the table on which Mr. Casaubon was leaning when he died.

Dublin Core:Title: Parerga
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Casaubon's published pamphlets^^ preliminary to his great unpublished "Key to all Mythologies"^^ "by which he tested his public and deposited small monumental records of his march."

Dublin Core:Title: Pegwell
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: Corn-factor.

Dublin Core:Title: John
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Sir James Chettam's groom.

Dublin Core:Title: Joseph
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Trumbill's assistant.

Dublin Core:Title: Kibble
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Silversmith in Brassing.

Dublin Core:Title: Lovegood
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Sir James Chettam's manager.

Dublin Core:Title: Mainwaring
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Fred Vincy's acquaintances.

Dublin Core:Title: Monk
Dublin Core:Subject: Pet Name
Dublin Core:Description: St. Bernard dog which takes care of Dorothea Brooke an dher sister in their walks.

Dublin Core:Title: Oliver
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A Middlemarch M.P.^^ who is to be turned out because he is a Peelite.

Dublin Core:Title: Pinkerton
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The old Tory member of Parliament from Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Protheroe
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Doctor from Brassing.

Dublin Core:Title: Tench
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Mr. Casaubon's critics.

Dublin Core:Title: Torbits
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A family in debt.

Dublin Core:Title: Tortoise
Dublin Core:Subject: Pet Name
Dublin Core:Description: The Garth's cat.

Dublin Core:Title: Trawley
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A friend of Lydgate's in his student days.

Dublin Core:Title: Truberry
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A politician who is ruled by his ambitious wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Vyan
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Fred Vincy's acquaintances.

Dublin Core:Title: Warburton
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A scholar whose assertions on the Egyptian mysteries Mr. Casaubon intends to correct.

Dublin Core:Title: Waule
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Waule's deceased husband^^ who had money.

Dublin Core:Title: Webbe
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Doctor from Crabsley.

Dublin Core:Title: Wright
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Mr. Brooke's servants.

Dublin Core:Title: Yoddrell
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Farmer.

Dublin Core:Title: "Benefit Club"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description:
An association in Middlemarch which considers taking Dr. Lydgate as its medical man. Benefit
Clubs are mentioned also in The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton^^ F. H. Benefit Clubs were clubs for mutual insurance against illness^^ unemployment^^ death^^ etc.

Dublin Core:Title: "Cultivation of Green Crops and the Economy of Cattle Feeding"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: Book written by Fred Vincy after he becomes a successful farmer.
Item Type Metadata:Text: "Cultivation of Green Crops and the Economy of Cattle Feeding"

Dublin Core:Title: "Dispute"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: A picture painted by Naumann^^ in which Mr. Casaubon is the model for St. Thomas Aquinas.

Dublin Core:Title: "Key to All Mythologies"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: The magnum opus which is the ambition of Mr. Casaubon's life and which he is unable to complete. "The difficulty of making his Key to all Mythologies unimpeachable weighted like lead upon his mind… even his religious faith wavered with his wavering trust in her own authorship."

Dublin Core:Title: "Messiah"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: An oratorio of which Caleb Garth is fond. The Messiah^^ by Handel.

Dublin Core:Title: "Middlemarch Pioneer"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: The paper which Mr. Brooke buys when he wishes to enter Parliament and which Will Ladislaw edits for him.

Dublin Core:Title: "Middlemarch Trumpet"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: The paper which opposes Mr. Brooke.

Dublin Core:Title: "O Me^^ O Me^^ What Frugal Cheer"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: The first line of a song written by Will Ladislaw.
Item Type Metadata:Text: "O Me^^ O Me^^ What Frugal Cheer"

Dublin Core:Title: "Supper at Emmaus^^ by Guido"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: A picture which Mr. Bulstrode asks Will Ladislaw to buy for him at the Larcher sale.

Dublin Core:Title: "Synoptical Tabulation"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: The outline^^ with directinos for continuing his "Key to all Mythologies"^^ which Mr. Casaubon leaves for Dorothea.

Dublin Core:Title: "Widgeon's Purifying Pills"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: A medicine much esteemed in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Bichat (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: A great French scientist whose work had inspired Dr. Lydgate. Marie Francois Xavier Bichat (1771-1802)^^ a French anatomist and physiologist.

Dublin Core:Title: Broussais (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: A French physician whom Lydgate knew when he was a student in Paris. Francois Joseph Victor Broussais (1772-1838)^^ a French physician whose lectures in Paris were attended by great numbers of students.

Dublin Core:Title: Cartwright (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: A gentleman at whose house Mr. Brooke had once dined with Sir Humphrey Davy and Wordsworth. Edmund Cartwright (1743-1823)^^ the inventor of the power-loom. His interest in agriculture led him into a correspondence with Sir Humphrey Davy. He was also the author of some published poems.

Dublin Core:Title: Cheshire^^ Mr. (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: A medical man who used "irons^^ trying to make people straight". Robert Chessher (1750-1831) a surgeon of Hinckly^^ Leicestershire^^ who had devised a special apparatus for weak spines. (See Garrison^^ History of Medicine^^ p. 518.)

Dublin Core:Title: Laennec^^ Dr. (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: A physician under whom Lydgate studied in Paris. Rene Theophile Hyacinthe Laennec (1781-1826)^^ a famous French physician^^ discoverer of auscultation of the heart^^ who taught in Paris from 1822.

Dublin Core:Title: Long^^ Mr. St. John (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description:
A medical charlatan^^ who claimed to have extracted mercury from the temples of a patient. John St. John Long (1798-
1834)^^ an ex-artist who established a medical practice in London in 1827^^ and claimed to have an entirely original method of treating consumption^^ etc. He was twice tried for manslaughter^^ and eventually died of a consumption which he refused to treat by his own method.

Dublin Core:Title: Louis (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: A French physician^^ a fever specialist^^ under whom Lydgate had studied in Paris. Pierre Charles Louis (1787-1872)^^ whose well known work on typhoid fever was published in 1829.

Dublin Core:Title: Romilly (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: A deceased acquaintance of Mr. Brooke's^^ who^^ if he were still living^^ could have helped to save Bruce^^ the sheep stealer^^ from hanging. Sir Samuel Romilly (1757-1818)^^ an English jurist and law reformer. He succeeded in having the death penalty abolished for a number of minor offences^^ including some kinds of stealing.

Dublin Core:Title: Stoddart (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Mr. Brooke's acquaintances^^ who said that women were not thinkers. Sir John Stoddart (1773-1856).

Dublin Core:Title: Thorwaldsen (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: An artist in Rome^^ to whose studio Will Ladislaw takes Mr. Casaubon and Dorothea. Bertel Thorwaldsen (1770-1844)^^ the well-known Danish sculptor^^ who lived in Rome for many years.

Dublin Core:Title: Wakley (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: A medical reformer of whom Dr. Sprague disapproves. Thomas Wakley (1795-1862)^^ a surgeon and medical reformer^^ founder of the Lancet. He attacked hospital administration and agitated for the reform of the College of Surgeons.

Dublin Core:Title: Wilberforce (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Mr. Brooke's early acquaintances^^ who worked at negro emancipation. William Wilberforce (1759-1833)^^ philanthropist and statesman who had dedicated himself to the abolition of the slave trade.

Dublin Core:Title: Wordsworth (Hist.)
Dublin Core:Subject: Historical Name
Dublin Core:Description: The poet^^ with whom Mr. Brooke had once dined at Cartwright's. William Wordsworth (1770-1850).

Dublin Core:Title: "Blue Bull"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Blue Bull"^^Inn in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: "Green Dragon"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Green Dragon"^^Public-house in Middlemarch where there was a billiard room^^ "which some anxious mothers and wives regarded as the chief temptation in Middlemarch."

Dublin Core:Title: "Green Man"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Green Man"^^Public-house at Brassing.

Dublin Core:Title: "Red Lion"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Red Lion"^^Inn at Houndsley.

Dublin Core:Title: "Saracen's Head"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Saracen's Head"^^Public-house in Bilkley.

Dublin Core:Title: "Tankard"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Tankard"^^Public-house in Middlemarch^^ the resort of a Benefit Club^^ which considers taking Doctor Lydgate as its medical man.

Dublin Core:Title: "Weights and Scales"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Weights and Scales"^^Public-house in Frick.

Dublin Core:Title: "White Hart"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "White Hart"^^Inn at Middlemarch^^ from the balcony of which Mr. Brooke addresses the electors of Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Blindman's Court
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Blindman's Court

Dublin Core:Title: Callum
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Garth's clerk.

Dublin Core:Title: Clemmens
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Solicitor in Brassing^^ who drew up Peter Featherstone's last will.

Dublin Core:Title: Corydon
Dublin Core:Subject: Pet Name
Dublin Core:Description: A chestnut horse belonging to Sir James Chettam.

Dublin Core:Title: Faulkner
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A gentleman to whom Mr. Bambridge had sold some horses.

Dublin Core:Title: Fletcher
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Hawley's clerk.

Dublin Core:Title: Garratt
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Servant at Freshitt Hall.

Dublin Core:Title: Grainger
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A sick man whom treatment reduced to a skeleton.

Dublin Core:Title: Gripp & Co.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Publishers in Middlemarch who print the book which Mary Garth writes for her children.

Dublin Core:Title: Ladislaw
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Will Ladislaw's deceased father^^ whom he resembles; a musician in poor health who had married the daughter of Mr. Bulstrod'es first wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Ladislaw
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Will Ladislaw's grandfather^^ a Polish refugee and musician; Mr. Casaubon's Aunt Julia had been disinherited for marrying him.

Dublin Core:Title: Music Master at Mrs. Lemon's School
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Rosamond Vincy's music teacher^^ the organist at St. Peter's. "Her master . . . was one of those exoellent musicians here and there to be found in our provinces . . . Rosamond^^ with the executant's instinct^^ had seized his manner of playing^^ and gave forth his large rendering of noble music with the precision of an echo . . . A hidden soul seemed to be flowing forth from Rosamond's fingers; and so indeed it was^^ since souls live on in perpetual echoes^^ and to all fine expression there goes somewhere an originating activity^^ if it be only that of an interpreter."
Dublin Core:Relation: Music Master at Mrs. Lemon's School

Dublin Core:Title: Pratt
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Casaubon's butler^^ "a red-cheeked man given to lively converse with Tantripp^^" Dorothea's maid.

Dublin Core:Title: Pritchard
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Servant in the Vincy family.

Dublin Core:Title: Sadler
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Draper in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Sally
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Garth's servant.

Dublin Core:Title: Simmons
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Featherstone's farm bailiff.

Dublin Core:Title: Tantripp
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Dorothea Brooke's lady's maid^^ who is much attached to her mistress.

Dublin Core:Title: Baldwin^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Tax-gatherer.

Dublin Core:Title: Ballard^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mistress of a school.

Dublin Core:Title: Bambridge^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Horse-dealer in Middlemarch^^ who lends money to Fred Vincy.

Dublin Core:Title: Bass^^ Trapping
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Poacher.

Dublin Core:Title: Beck^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lodging-house keeper.

Dublin Core:Title: Beevor^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The captain's wife^^ step-daughter to Lord Grinsell.

Dublin Core:Title: Bowyer^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An idle bachelor addicted to comic songs and ventriloquism.

Dublin Core:Title: Bretton^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Former owner of the house in which the Lydgates live.

Dublin Core:Title: Brooke^^ Mr. Arthur
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Bachelor uncle and guardian of Dorothea and Celia. " A man nearly sixty^^ of acquiescent temper^^ miscellaneous opinions^^ and uncertain vote. He had travelled in his younger years^^ and was held in this part of the county to have contracted a too rambling habit of mind. Mr. Brooke's conclusions were as difficult to predict as the weather; it was only safe to say that he would act with benevolent intentions^^ and that he would spend as little money as possible in carrying them out." He takes his responsibilities towards his nieces very lightly^^ and^^ although disapproving of the elderly Mr. Casaubon as a husband for Dorothea^^ makes only a ridiculously inadequate remonstrance when she announces her intention of marrying him. Later^^ when he plunges into politics and wishes to run for Parliament^^ he engages the services of Will Ladislaw and retains him in the neighbourhood to the displeasure of jealous Mr. Casaubon. When Dorothea^^ then a young widow^^ marries Will Ladislaw^^ he is unable to manifest any serious displeasure and^^ although he at first talks of cutting the entail^^ her eldest son eventually inherits his estates.

Dublin Core:Title: Brooke^^ Celia
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Dorothea's pretty and proper younger sister. "The rural opinion about the new young ladies^^ even among the cottagers^^ was generally in favour of Celia^^ as being so amiable and innocent-looking… Since they could remember^^ there had been a mixture of criticism and awe in the attitude of Celia's mind towards her elder sister. The younger had always worna yoke; but is there any yoked creature without its private opinions?" "But on safe opportunities she had an indirect mode of making her negative wisdom tell upon Dorothea^^ and calling her down from her rhapsodic mood by reminding her that people were staring^^ not listening. Celia was not impulsive; what she had to say could wait^^ and came from her always with the same quite staccato evenness." Her sense of propriety is often shocked by Dorothea's unconventional views and deeds^^ and she occasionally has courage to utter her criticisms. She dislikes Mr. Casaubon^^ to whose blinking and moles she strongly objects. After Dorothea marries Mr. Casaubon^^ Celia makes a very happy marriage with the correct Sir James Chettam^^ and feels an affectionate superiority to her sister^^ as one who has managed her life less well. her real affection for Dorothea does not allow her to be parted from her^^ even when she greatly disapproves of her second marriage. The original of Celia Brooke was George Eliot's elder sister^^ Christiana Evans^^ later Mrs. Edward Clarke^^ although the character of Celia is not an exact portrait of her sister.

Dublin Core:Title: Brooke^^ Dorothea
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A beautiful^^ noble-minded and ardent girl^^ with an intense longing for goodness and a great desire to be helpful to others. "Miss Brooke had that kind of beauty which seems to be thrown into relief by poor dress. Her hand and wrist were so finely formed that she could wear sleeves not less bare of style than those in which the Blessed Vergin appeared to Italian painters; and her profile as well as her stature and bearing seemed to gain the more dignity from her plain garments^^ which by the side of provincial fashion gave her the impressiveness of a fine quotation from the Bible--or from one of our elder poets--in a paragraph of today's newspaper. She was usually spoken of as being remakably clever^^ but with the addition that sister Celia had more common-sense." "She came into the drawing room in her silver-grey dress--the simple lines of her dark brown hair parted over her brown and coiled massively behind^^ in keeping with the entire absence from her manner and expression of all searc after mere effect. Sometimes when Dorothea was in the company there seemed to be as complete an air of repose about her as if she had been a picture of Santa Barbara." "The intensity of her religious disposition^^ the coercion it exercised over her life was but one aspect of a nature altogether ardent^^ theoretic and intellectually consequent; and with such a nature struggling in the bands of a narrow teaching^^ hemmed in by social life which seemed nothing but a labyrinth of petty courses^^ a walled-in maze of small paths that led no whither^^ the outcome was sure to strike others as at once exaggeration and inconsistency." Dorothea at nineteen marries the middle-aged and pedantic Mr. Casaubon because she is in love with the idea of being a helpmate to him in his great work. She soon realizes that she has idealized her husband^^ who is a cold^^ jealous^^ and selfish man^^ engaged in a work of no real value. Although the shock of the disilluison is great and her intense nature at times rebels^^ she loyally devotes herself to Mr. Casaubon while he lives. She is on the point of sacrificing her future happiness by making him a promise^^ which^^ though she does not know its nature^^ would have separated her from Will Ladislaw^^ his young cousin^^ when Mr. Casaubon dies. Eventually she gives up her social position and Mr. Casaubon's money in order to marry Will Ladislaw. Dorothea's religious side was drawn^^ recognizably^^ from letters to George Eliot from Emilia Strong^^ who became first Mrs. mark Pattison and later Lady Dilke. There are points in her character--her opinions and her relation to her sister--which were suggested by things in George Eliot's own life.

Dublin Core:Title: Bulstrode^^ Ellen
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. and Mrs. Bulstrode's daughter.

Dublin Core:Title: Bulstrode^^ Mrs. Harriet
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The banker's handsome and loyal wife^^ and Mr. Vincy's sister. "But this imperfectly taught woman^^ whose phrases and habits were an odd patchwork^^ had a loyal spirit within her. The man whose prosperity she had shared through nearly half a life^^ and who had unvaryingly cherished her--now that punishment had befallen him^^ it was not possible to her in any sense to forsake him. There is a forsaking which still sits at the same board and lies on the same couch with the forsaken soul^^ withering it the more by unloving proximity. She knew when she locked her door^^ that she should unlock it ready to go down to her unhappy husband and espouse his sorrow^^ and say of his guilt^^ I will mourn and not reproach. But she needed time to gather up her strength; she needed to sob out her farewell to all the gladness and pride of her life." Of a wholesome worldy nature she frankly enjoyes her husband's wealth and position before scandal touches him. When she learns of his unworthiness her loyalty to him never wavers^^ although she suffers greatly.

Dublin Core:Title: Bulstrode^^ Kate
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. and Mrs. Bulstrode's daughter.

Dublin Core:Title: Bulstrode^^ Mr. Nicholas
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Banker in Middlemarch; a man whose marked piety covers a dishonourable past. "He had a pale blonde skin^^ thin grey besprinkled brown hair^^ light-grey eyes^^ and a large forehead. Loud men called his subdued tone an undertone^^ and sometimes implied that it was inconsistent with openness... Mr. Bulstrode had also a deferential bending attitude in listening and an apparently fixed attentiveness in his eyes which made those persons who thought themselves worth hearing infer that he was seeking the utmost improvement from their discourse." "Strange^^ piteous conflict in the soul of this unhappy man^^ who had longed for years to be better than he was--who had taken his selfish passions into discipline and clad them in severe robes^^ so that he had walked with them as a devout choir." He had been connected with a London pawnshop^^ which dealt with thieves^^ had married his employer's rich widow^^ after concealing from her the fact that her daughter^^ Will Ladislaw's mother^^ for whom she was searching^^ was alive^^ had inherited her money on her death^^ and settled in Middlemarch. Here he married Mr. Vincy's sister^^ and made a place for himself as a prosperous man interested in philanthropy. When Raffles^^ who knows of his early life^^ appears in Middlemarch^^ Mr. Bulstrode bribes him to keep silent. He treis to atone for his action about his first wife's daughter by offerin gmoney to her son^^ Will Ladislaw^^ when he learns of the relationship^^ only to have his offer refused. During Raffles' last illness Mr. Bulstrode knowingly allows Dr. Lydgate's orders to be disobeyed^^ and Raffles dies^^ but Mr. Bulstrode's secret has become known^^ and he leaves Middlemarch a disgraced man^^ involving Lydgate^^ who had accepted a loan from him^^ in his disgrace.

Dublin Core:Title: Byles^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Butcher in Middlemarch^^ to whom Lydgate owed money.

Dublin Core:Title: Cadwallader^^ Mrs. Elinor
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The rector's managing wife; a high-born^^ sharp-tongued lady fond of a joke."A lady of immeasurably high birth^^ descended^^ as it were^^ from unknown earls^^ dim as the crowd of heroic shades--who pleaded poverty^^ pared down prices^^ and cut jokes in the most companionable manner^^ though with a turn of tongue that let you know who she was. Such a lady gave a neighbourliness to both rank and religion^^ and mitigated the bitterness of uncommuted tithe. A much more exemplary character with an infusion of sour dignity would not have furthered their comprehension of the Thirty-nine Articles^^ and would have been less socially uniting."

Dublin Core:Title: Cadwallader^^ Mr. Humphrey
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Rector of Tipton and Freshitt; an easy-going man^^ noted for his devotion to fishing. "Mr. Cadwallader was a large man^^ with full lips and a sweet smile; very plain and rough in his exterior^^ but with that solid imperturbable ease and goodhumour which is infectious^^ and like great grassy hills in the sunshine^^ quiets even an irritated egoism^^ and makes it rather ashamed of itself . . . He always saw the joke of any satire against himself. His conscience was large and easy^^ like the rest of him; it did only what it could do without any trouble."

Dublin Core:Title: Carter^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Brooke's cook.

Dublin Core:Title: Casaubon^^ Reverend Edward
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description:
A pedantic^^ middle-aged scholar^^ intensely self-centred and jealous. "Mr. Casaubon had never had a strong bodily frame^^ and his soul was sensitive without being enthusiastic; it was too languid to thrill out of self-consciousness
into passionate delight; it went on fluttering in the swampy ground where it was hatched^^ thinking of its wings and never flying. His experience was of that pitiable kind which shrinks from pity^^ and fears most of all that it should be
known; it was that proud^^ narrow sensitiveness which has not mass enough to spare for transformation into sympathy^^ and quivers thread-like in small currents of self-preoccupation or at best of an egoistic scrupulosity. And Mr. Casaubon had many scruples; he was capable of severe self-restraint; resolute he was in being a man of honour according to the code; he would be unimpeachable by any recognized opinion . . . the difficulty of making his Key to all Mythologies unimpeachable weighed like lead upon his mind . . . even his religious faith wavered with his wavering trust in his own authorship^^ and the consolations of the Christian hope in immortality seemed to lean on the immortality of the still unwritten Key to all Mythologies." He marries Dorothea Brooke^^ who has idealized him^^ and soon proves himself selfishly blind to her claims^^ and incapable of responding to her devotion. His ambition is centred in his projected masterpiece^^ "Key to all Mythologies^^" but he lacks the ability necessary to carry it to completion. Because Dorothea manifests a friendly interest in his young kinsman^^ Will Ladislaw^^ he becomes unreasonably jealous^^ and when he dies some two years after his marriage^^ he leaves a codicil to his will depriving Dorothea of his property in case she marries Ladislaw. It has been claimed by some that the Reverend Mark pattison^^ Rector of Lincoln^^ was the original of Mr. Casaubon^^ while others have indignantly denied this. Mark Pattison was a visitor at George Eliot's home^^ and it is possible that she may^^ unconsciously^^ have copied some of his superficial characteristics. This^^ together with the name--Mark Pattison's best known work was his life of Isaac Casaubon--may have given rise to the report that he was the original. (See article by Lord Acton in Nineteenth Century^^ vol. 17^^ p. 480; Morley^^ Critical Miscellanies^^ vol. 3^^ p. 165; chapter by Mrs. Lynn Lynton^^ in Women Novelists of Queen Victoria's Reign^^ p. 100; article in Academy^^ 9th August^^ 1884.)

Dublin Core:Title: Chettam^^ Dowager Lady
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mother of Sir James; a statley^^ affable woman.

Dublin Core:Title: Chettam^^ Arthur
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Sir James and Lady Chettam's little son^^ named after Mr. Brooke.

Dublin Core:Title: Chettam^^ Sir James
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An amiable^^ prosperous and handsome baronet^^ with a great dislike for the unconventional. "He was made of excellent human dough^^ and had the rare merit of knowing that his talents^^ even if let loose^^ would not set the smallest stream in the country on fire; hence he liked the prospect of a wife to whom he could say: 'What shall we do?' about this or that; who could help her husband out with reasons^^ and would also have the property qualification for doing so." He is in love with Dorothea Brooke^^ whose superiority he reccognizes^^ and he is much shocked when she marries the elderly Mr. Casaubon. He soon transfers his affectinos to her sister Celia^^ and becomes an affectionate and indulgent husband. He loyally retains an admiration for Dorothea and opposes her second marriage^^ which he considers unworthy of her.

Dublin Core:Title: Chichely^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Coroner in Middlemarch. "A middle-aged bachelor and coursing celebrity^^ who had a complexion something like an Easter egg^^ a few hairs carefully arranged^^ and a carriage implying the consciousness of a distinguished appearance."

Dublin Core:Title: Clintup^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "A diffident though distinguished nurseryman."

Dublin Core:Title: Cooper^^ Timothy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Farm labourer.

Dublin Core:Title: Crabbe^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "Glazier who gathered much news^^" a frequenter of the "Tankard".

Dublin Core:Title: Cranch^^ Mrs. Martha
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Peter Featherstone's poor sister; a wheezy old woman anxious to inherit some of her brother's riches.

Dublin Core:Title: Cranch^^ Tom
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Cranch's unattractive son^^ who is sent to watch during his uncle's last illness. "Young Cranch was not exactly the balancing point between the wit and the idiot--verging slightly toward the latter type^^ and squinting so as to leave everything in doubt about his sentiments except that they were not of a forcible character."

Dublin Core:Title: Croly^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A celebrated beauty in 1790.

Dublin Core:Title: Crowse^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Curate^^ "with empty face and near umbrella and mincing little speeches."

Dublin Core:Title: Dagley^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Farmer on Mr. Brooke's estate.

Dublin Core:Title: Dagley^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The farmer's little son^^ caught by Mr. Brooke killing a leveret.

Dublin Core:Title: Dill^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Barber in Middlemarch; a frequenter of the "Tankard"^^ who feels himself a little above the company there.

Dublin Core:Title: Dollop^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The spirited landlady of the "Tankard"^^ Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Dover^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Silversmith^^ Lydgate's chief creditor^^ who is willing to take back a portion of the plate and jewellery.

Dublin Core:Title: Downes^^ Kit
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Farmer on Mr. Brooke's land.

Dublin Core:Title: Duncan^^ Archie
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A spiteful admirer of Sarah Dunkirk's^^ who had told her of her parent's disreputable business.

Dublin Core:Title: Dunkirk^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A rich London pawnbroker^^ Mr. Bulstrode's early patron^^ who made his fortune by conducting a receiving house for stolen goods.

Dublin Core:Title: Dunkirk^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The pawnbroker's wife^^ "a simple pious woman"; later Mr. Bulstrode's first wife. On her husband's death she inherited his wealth^^ never having realized the nature of his business. She refused to marry Mr. Bulstrode until efforts had been made to find her lost daughter. Mr. Bulstrode concealed his knowledge of the daughter's whereabouts^^ and Mrs. Dunkirk married him and left him her fortune without reservation.

Dublin Core:Title: Dunkirk^^ Sarah
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Will Ladislaw's mother; Mr. and Mrs. Dunkirk's proud-spirited daughter. When she learned the dishonourable nature of her father's business^^ she ran away from home^^ went on the stage and later married Mr. Ladislaw^^ a Polish refugee.

Dublin Core:Title: Farebrother^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The vicar's mother^^ a formal and precise old lad. "The vicar's white-haired mother^^ befrilled and kerchiefed with dainty cleanliness^^ upright^^ quick-eyed^^ and still under seventy. . . . The old lady was evidently accustomed to tell her company what they ought to think^^ and to regard no subject as quite safe without her steering. She was afforded leisure for this function by having all her little wants attended to by Miss Winifred."

Dublin Core:Title: Farebrother^^ Reverend Camden
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description:
Vicar of St. Botolph's^^ Middlemarch; a generous^^ honourable man with a gift for good preaching^^ and a liking for natural science. "It went along with other points of conduct in Mr. Farebrother which were exceptionally fine^^ and made his character resemble those southern landscapes which seem divided between natural grandeur and social slovenliness. Very few men could have been as filial and chivalrous as he was to the mother^^ aunt^^ and sister^^ whose dependence on him had in many ways shaped his life rather uneasily for himself... Then^^ his preaching was ingenious and pithy^^ like the preaching of the English Church in its robust age^^ and his sermons were delivered without book. People outside his pariah went to hear him; and since to fill the church was always the most difficult part of a clergyman's function^^ here was another ground for a careless sense of superiority. Besides^^ he was a likeable man; sweet- tempered^^ ready- witted^^ frank^^ without grins of supprellled bitterness or other conversational
flavours which make half of us an affliction to our friends." On an insufficient income he has to aupport hie mother^^ aunt^^ and sister^^ and so is led into card-playing for money. For the same reason he would like to obtain the salaried chaplaincy of Bulstrode's new hospital^^ but from a sense of delicacy refrains from asking Lydgate^^ who has the deciding vote^^ to aid his candidacy against Bulstrode's candidate^^ Mr. Tyke. He is in love with Mary Garth^^ but renounces his own hopes in that direction in order to help Fred Vincy win Mary. Through Lydgate Mrs. Casaubon becomes interested in him and gives him the desirable Lowick living.

Dublin Core:Title: Farebrother^^ Miss Winifred
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The vicar's elder sister^^ "well-looking like himself^^ but nipped and subdued^^ as si9ngle women are apt to be who spend their lives in uninterrupted subjection to their elders."

Dublin Core:Title: Featherstone^^ Jonah
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Peter's poor brother^^ the wit of the family^^ who had come down in the world^^ and is one of those who are on the watch lest Peter's money be left out of the family.

Dublin Core:Title: Featherstone^^ Mr. Peter
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A rich and miserly old widower^^ owner of Stone Court. "Old Featherstone had not been a Harpagon whose passions had all been devoured by the ever-lean and ever-hungry passion of saving^^ and who would drive a bargain with his undertaker beforehand. He loved money^^ but he also loved to spend it in gratifying his peculiar tastes^^ and perhaps he loved it best of all as a means of making others feel his power more or less uncomfort ably. If anyone will here contend that there must have been traits of goodness in old Featherstone^^ I will not presume to deny this; but I mart observe that goodness is of a modest nature^^ easily discouraged^^ and^^ when much elbowed in early life by unabashed vices^^ is apt to retire into extreme privacy^^ so that it is more easily believed in by those who con struct a selfish old gentleman theoretically^^ than by those who form the narrower judgments based on his personal acquaintance." He is connected with the Garths through his first wife and with the Vincys through his second wife^^ and has a host of relatives of his own who are anxious that he shall not leave his money outside his family. He enjoys arousing speculation as to his intentions^^ and leads Fred Vincy to expect a bequest^^ but disappoints him^^ as well as all his own greedy and scheming relatives^^ by leaving his property to a hitherto unheard-of natural son^^ Joshua Rigg. He has made many wills and at the end^^ when dying and helpless^^ he wants this will destroyed so that an earlier one providing for Fred will be operative^^ but cannot carry out his wishes.

Dublin Core:Title: Featherstone^^ Rigg^^ otherwise known as Mr. Joshua Rigg
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Peter Featherstone's frog-faced natural son. "Socially speaking^^ Joshua Rigg would have been generally pronounced a superfluity… Mr. Rigg Featherstone's low characteristics were all of the sober^^ water-drinking kind. From the earliest to the latest hour of the day he was always as sleek^^ neat^^ and cool as the frog he resembled^^ and old Peter had secretly chuckled over this offshoot almost more calculating^^ and far more imperturbable^^ than himself." His existence is unknown to the Featherstones until^^ at his father's death^^ he appears at Stone Court and inherits Peter's land^^ to the rage and disappointment of the Featherstone family. As his chief ambition is to be a money-changer^^ he sells his property to Mr. Bulstrode and departs from Middlemarch. His disreputable stepfather^^ Raffles^^ follows him to Stone Court^^ and this leads eventually to the discovery of Mr. Bulstrodes early life.
Dublin Core:Relation: Featherstone^^ Rigg^^ otherwise known as Mr. Joshua Rigg

Dublin Core:Title: Featherstone^^ Solomon
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Peter's rich and greedy brother^^ also on the watch for Peter's money. " He was a large-cheeked man^^ nearly seventy^^ with small furtive eyes and was not only of much blander temper^^ but thought himself much deeper than his brother Peter; indeed^^ not likely to be deceived in any of his feJ1owmen inasmuch as they could not well be more greedy and deceitful than he suspected them of being. Even the invisible powers^^ he thought^^ were likely to be soothed by a bland parenthesis here and there-coming from a man of property^^ who might have been as impious as others.

Dublin Core:Title: Fitchett^^ Master
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The husband of the lodge-keeper at Tipton Grange.

Dublin Core:Title: Fitchett^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lodge-keeper at Tipton Grange.

Dublin Core:Title: Ford^^ Hiram
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A wagoner.

Dublin Core:Title: Gambit^^ Doctor
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Medical man of the Benefit club in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Garth^^ Alfred
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. and Mrs. Garth's son who is destined to be an engineer.

Dublin Core:Title: Garth^^ Ben
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mary's youngest brother; "an energetic young male with a heavy brow^^" who hates grammar.

Dublin Core:Title: Garth^^ Caleb
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Land agest and builder; a man with a storng sense of honour and an enthusiastic interest in his work. "A large amount of painful experience had not sufficed to make Cable Garth cautious about his own affairs^^ or distrustful of his fellow-men when they had not proved themselves un trustworthy. ... He was one of those rare men who are rigid to themselves and indulgent to others. He had a certain shame about his neighbour's errors^^ and never spoke of them willingly." "His virtual divinities were good^^ practical schemes^^ accurate work^^ and the faithful completion of undertakings: his prince of darkness was a slack workman. ... In fact^^ he had a reverential soul with a strong^^ practical intelligence. But he could not manage finance: he knew values well^^ but he had no keenness of imagination for monetary results in the shape of profit and loss: and having ascertained this to his cost^^ he determined to give up all forms of his beloved 'business' which required that talent. He . . . was one of those precious men within his own district whom everybody would choose to work for them^^ because he did his work well^^ charged very little^^ and often declined to charge at all. It is no wonder^^ then^^ that the Garths were poor^^ and 'lived in a small way However^^ they did not mind it." "With regard to a large number of matters about which other men are decided or obstinate^^ he was the most easily manageable man in the world. He never knew what meat he would choose; and if Susan had said that they ought to live in a fourroomed cottage^^ in order to save^^ he would have said^^ 'Let us go^^' without inquiring into details. But where Caleb's feeling and judgment strongly pronounced^^ he was a ruler; and in spite of his mildness and timidity in reproving^^ every one about him knew that on the exceptional occasion^^ when he chose^^ he was absolute."  He had failed in the building business but had eventually paid his creditors in full. He has faith in Fred Vincy^^ and when Fred disappoints his own family by deciding not to enter the Church^^ he takes him into his office as his assistant^^ at the cost of additional work for himself^^ and gives him help that enables him to marry his daughter Mary. He accepts a good position from Mr. Bulstrode^^ but when he learns of Mr. Bulstrode's dishonest career^^ his uncompromising honesty forces him to give this up. It is generally agreed that many of Caleb Garth's marked characteristics —his occupation as builder and land agent^^ his uncompromising uprightness^^ delight in his work^^ love of the soil^^ perhaps even his domestic submissiveness — were drawn from Robert Evans^^ George Eliot's father^^ although the character is not an exact portrait of the original. (See Cooke^^ George Eliot^^ pp. 4-5; Cross^^ George Eliot's Life^^ vol. 1^^ p. 2; Dictionary of National Biography^^ article Cross^^ Mary Ann.)

Dublin Core:Title: Garth^^ Christy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. Garth^^ who has taken to books instead of business. "Christy^^ who held it the most desirable thing in the world to be a tutor^^ to study all literatures and be a regenerate Porson… a square-browed^^ broad-shouldered masculine edition of his mother... was always as simple as possible."

Dublin Core:Title: Garth^^ Jim
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Young son of Mr. and Mrs. Garth.

Dublin Core:Title: Garth^^ Letty
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mary's little sister.

Dublin Core:Title: Garth^^ Mary
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Elder daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Garth; an attractive girl with plain features^^ a clever tongue^^ a sense of humour^^ and a warm heart. "Mary Garth ... had the aspect of an ordinary sinner: she was brown; her curly dark hair was rough and stubborn; her stature was low: and it would not be true to declare in satisfactory antithesis^^ that she had all the virtues . . . Advancing womanhood had tempered her plainness^^ which was of a good human sort^^ such as the mothers of our race have very commonly worn in all latitudes under a more or less becoming headgear. Rembrandt would have painted her with pleasure^^ and would have made her broad features look out of the canvas with intelligent honesty.
