For honesty^^ truth-telling fairness^^ was Mary's reigning virtue: she neither tried to create illusions^^ nor indulged in them for her own behoof^^ and when she was in a good mood she had humour enough in her to laugh at herself." "She had a broad face and square brow^^ well-marked eyebrows and curly dark hair^^ a certain expression of amusement in her glance which her mouth keeps the secret of^^ and for the rest^^ features entirely insignificant.... If you made her smile^^ she would show you perfect little teeth; if you made her angry^^ she would not raise her voice^^ but would probably say one of the bitterest things you have ever tested the flavour of; if you did her a kindness^^ she would never forget it."  As children^^ she and Fred Vincy had been sweethearts^^ and no one else ever replaces him in her affections^^ although she shows much scorn for his imperfections^^ and steadily opposes his plan of taking orders^^ for which she thinks he is not suited. While she has great admiration for Mr. Farebrother^^ who is in love with her^^ she remains faithful to Fred and marries him after saying^^ "I should never like scolding any one else so well^^ and that is a point to be thought of in a husband."

Dublin Core:Title: Garth^^ Mrs. Susan
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Caleb's wife; a good^^ unworldly woman with much force and some oddities of character. "Mrs. Garth never committed herself by over-hasty speech; having^^ as she said^^ borne the yoke in her youth^^ and learned self-control. She had that rare sense which discerns what is unalterable^^ and submits to it without murmuring. Adoring her husband's virtues^^ she had very early made up her mind to his incapacity of minding his own interests^^ and had met the consequences cheerfully. She had been magnanimous enough to renounce all pride in tea-pots or children's frilling. . . . She had sometimes taken pupils in a peripatetic fashion^^ making them follow her about in the kitchen with their book or slate." Devoted entirely to her family^^ she is anxious to have her husband's good qualities and solid work appreciated at their full value and to give the children as good an education as possible^^ training them herself while they are small^^ and scheming and planning for their further education. Although she has always regarded Fred Vincy with a motherly feeling^^ she is disappointed when her daughter Mary accepts him as a husband when she might have married Mr. Farebrother.

Dublin Core:Title: Goby^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A patient that Dr. Lydgate "had wanted to cut up".

Dublin Core:Title: Griffin^^ and Wife
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Parishioners of Mr. Tyke's.

Dublin Core:Title: Grinsell^^ Lord
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An acquaintance of the Dowager Lady Chettam.

Dublin Core:Title: Hackbutt^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A rich tanner of fluent speech^^ a leading citizen of Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Hackbutt^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The tanner's wife^^ who thinks that Mrs. Bulstrode should part from her husband.

Dublin Core:Title: Hackbutt^^ Fanny
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Mrs. Garth's pupils.

Dublin Core:Title: Hanmer^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Engineer to whom Alfred Garth is to be apprenticed.

Dublin Core:Title: Harfager^^ Clara
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A girl with some money^^ "whose friends don't know what to do for her."

Dublin Core:Title: Hawley^^ Arabella
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A young lady who had gone into a consumption.

Dublin Core:Title: Hawley^^ Mr. Frank
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyer and town clerk in Middlemarch^^ notorious for his bad language. He is one of Mr. Bulstrode's chief opponents.

Dublin Core:Title: Hawley^^ young
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A law student who is an accomplished billiard player.

Dublin Core:Title: Hopkins^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Draper in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Horrock^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "The vet^^" a non-committal man of neutral expression in whose company Fred Vincy goes to Houndsley horse-fair. "Costume^^ at a glance^^ gave him a thrilling association with horses (enough to specify the hat-brim which took the slightest upward angle just to escape the suspicion of bending downward)^^ and nature had given him a face which by dint of Mongolian eyes^^ and a nose^^ mouth^^ and chin seeming to follow his hat brim in a moderate inclination upward^^ gave the effect of a subdued unchangeable skeptical smile."

Dublin Core:Title: Job^^ Old
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A man who speaks in dialect.

Dublin Core:Title: Jonas^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Dyer.

Dublin Core:Title: Julia^^ Aunt
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Casaubon's aunt^^ who had made a runaway match and been disinherited; Will Ladislaw's grandmother.

Dublin Core:Title: Keck^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Editor of the "Middlemarch Trumpet".

Dublin Core:Title: Kell^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Housekeeper at Tipton Grange.

Dublin Core:Title: Ladislaw^^ Will
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Casaubon's second cousin; a generous^^ gay^^ and rather irresponsible young man with Bohemian tendencies. "Will Ladislaw's smile was delightful^^ unless you were angry with him beforehand; it was a gush of inward light illuminating the transparent skin as well as the eyes^^ and playing about every curve and line as if some Ariel were touching them with a new charm^^ and banishing forever the traces of moodiness . . . The first impression on seeing Will was one of sunny brightness^^ which added to the uncertainty of his changing expression. Surely^^ his very features changed their form; his jaw looked sometimes large and sometimes small; and the little ripple in his nose was a preparation for metamorphosis. When he turned his head quickly his hair seemed to shake out light^^ and some persons thought they saw decided genius in this coruscation." His grandmother^^ Mr. Casaubon's aunt^^ had been disinherited because she made a mesalliance^^ by marrying a poor Pole^^ and Mr. Casaubon^^ who feels an inherited responsibility for this^^ had educated Will. With artistic tastes^^ some ability as a writer^^ and a disregard for worldly considerations he has some difficulty in choosing a profession. When he meets Dorothea as Mr. Casaubon's wife he first becomes interested in her^^ and then grows to love her with constancy and devotion^^ and for the sake of being near her settles in Middlemarch as editor of Mr. Brooke's paper. His sense of honour causes him to refuse Mr. Bulstrode's offer of money^^ dishonestly gained^^ which should have been his mother's. When Dorothea^^ after a short widowhood^^ gives up position and fortune to marry him^^ he enters public life^^ without promise of marked success. It has been suggested that some traits in the character of Will Ladislaw were drawn^^ perhaps unconsciously^^ from George Henry Lewes^^ who^^ also^^ was a man of versatile talent and lively manner. Some critics^^ however^^ do not recognize Lewes as the original. Those who consider Lewes as the prototype find one of their arguments in the author's very evident fondness for the character of Ladislaw. (See Bonnell^^ Charlotte Bronte^^ George Eliot^^ Jane Austen^^ p. 240 ; Deakin^^ Early Life of George Eliot^^ p. 89: Parkinson^^ Scenes from the George Eliot Country^^ p. 140.)

Dublin Core:Title: Lamb^^ Leonard^^ B.A.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An acquaintance of Mr. Raffles^^ called Ba-Lamb.

Dublin Core:Title: Larcher^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The carrier's wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Larcher^^ Mr. Caius
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A young dandy of Middlemarch whom Rosamond Vincy looks down on.

Dublin Core:Title: Larcher^^ Edwin^^ Esq.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A prosperous carrier^^ who has a sale when he moves. It is at this sale that Will Ladislaw is recognized by Raffles.

Dublin Core:Title: Laure^^ Madame
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lydgate's first love^^ a beautiful French actress. Having tired of her husband^^ whom she was supposed to stab in a play^^ she turned the play into reality and killed him^^ and later told Lydgate that she did not like husbands.

Dublin Core:Title: Lemon^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mistress of the school where Rosamond Vincy was educated. "The chief school in the county^^ hwer the teaching included all that was demanded in the accomplished female--even to extras^^ such as the getting in and out of a carriage."

Dublin Core:Title: Liret^^ Monsieur
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Vaudois clergyman in Lausanne^^ who gave conference on the history of the Waldenses.

Dublin Core:Title: Lydgate^^ Captain
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Sir Godwin's third son; a fop and a critic of feminine charms^^ whose admiration greatly pleases Rosamond and leads her to disobey her husband and so lose her baby.

Dublin Core:Title: Lydgate^^ Charles
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Tertius Lydgate's uncle.

Dublin Core:Title: Lydgate^^ Sir Godwin
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Uncle of Tertius Lydgate^^ who refuses to help his nephew when he is in need of money.

Dublin Core:Title: Lydgate^^ Tertius
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A talented young doctor with a great enthusiasm for the best in his profession. "One of Lydgate's gifts was a voice habitually deep and sonorous^^ yet capable of becoming very low and gentle at the right moment. About his ordinary bearing there was a certain fling^^ a fearless expectation of success^^ aconfidence in his own powers and integrity^^ much fortified by contempt for petty obstacles or seductions of which he had had no experience. But this proud openness was made lovable by an expression of unaffected good will." "His scientific interest soon took the form of a professional enthusiasm; he had a youthful belief in his bread-winning work . . . and he carried to his studies . . . the conviction that the medical profession as it might be was the finest in the world . . . But he did not simply aim at a more genuine kind of practice than was common. He was ambitious of a wider effect : he was fired with the possibility that he might work out the proof of an anatomical conception and make a link in the chain of discovery . . . Lydgate was ambitious above all to contribute towards enlarging the scientific^^ rational basis of his profession." He settles in Middlemarch^^ intending not only to be a good doctor^^ but also to carry on scientific investigation^^ for which he is well fitted. Captivated by Rosamond Vincy's beauty and grace^^ he marries her and soon discovers that she is absolutely selfish and unresponsive to his tender love^^ with no sympathy for his high aims. His opposition to accepted medical usages makes him unpopular with the other physicians of Middlemarch^^ and his connexion with Mr. Bulstrode leads him into trouble. His wife has only blame for him^^ and all his endeavours to economize are stubbornly opposed by her. The struggle between him and Rosamond^^ who demands position and luxury at any price^^ ends in the subjection of his higher self^^ and his noblest aims are sacrificed to worldly success. To meet the demands of her ambition he is forced to move to London^^ and become a fashionable physician^^ and dies there at a comparatively early age. The high-minded^^ medical side of Lydgate is said to have been drawn from the Rt. Hon. Sir T. Clifford Allbutt^^ Regius Professor of Physic^^ Cambridge^^ who^^ when Middlemarch was written^^ was head of the Leeds Fever Hospital which George Eliot visited. The portraiture is but partial and the circumstances different. (Manuscript notes.) George Eliot's friend and biographer^^ Mr. Oscar Browning^^ has also been suggested as the prototype^^ in part. (Browning^^ Memories of Sixty Years^^ p. 193.)

Dublin Core:Title: Mawmsey^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Grocer^^ the chief representative of the retail trader in Middlemarch. "Mr. Mawmsey was not only an overseer ... he was also asthmatic and had an increasing family ... he was an important man; indeed^^ an exceptional grocer^^ whose hair was arranged in a flame-like pyramid^^ and whose retail deference was of the cordial^^ encouraging kind--jocosely complimentary^^ and with a certain considerate abstinence from letting out the full force of his mind."

Dublin Core:Title: Mawmsey^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The grocer's wife^^ the mother of a large family who has a great esteem for medicine.

Dublin Core:Title: Medlicote^^ Lord
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A patron of Mr. Bulstrode's hospital^^ who has given the land and the timber.

Dublin Core:Title: Megatherium^^ Lord
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A gouty old nobleman.

Dublin Core:Title: Mengan^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Captain Lydgate's sister^^ who stays two nights with Rosamond on her way from town.

Dublin Core:Title: Minchin^^ Dr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of the two leading physicians of Middlemarch^^ who opposes Lydgate and his innovations. " He objected to the rather free style of anecdote in which Dr. Sprague indulged^^ preferring wellsanctioned quotations^^ and liking refinement of all kinds ; it was generally known that he had some kinship to a bishop^^ and some times spent his holidays at 'the palace'. "Dr. Minchin was soft-handed^^ pale-complexioned^^ and of rounded outline^^ not to be distinguished from a mild clergyman in appearance."

Dublin Core:Title: Morgan^^ Miss
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Governess in the Vincy family. "Miss Morgan^^ who was brown^^ dull^^ and resigned^^ and altogether^^ as Miss Vincy often said^^ just the sort of person for a governess."

Dublin Core:Title: Nash^^ Nancy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A charwoman^^ who is cured by Dr. Lydgate after her illness had been incorrectly diagnosed by Dr. Minchin.

Dublin Core:Title: Naumann^^ Adolf
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A good-natured German painter in Rome who admires the beauty of Mrs. Casaubon so much that he asks Mr. Casaubon to sit for Thomas Aquinas^^ in order to have an opportunity of painting Dorothea. The character of Naumann was probably suggested by Johann Friedrich Overbeck (1789-1869)^^ a German artist who worked at Rome 1810-1869. (See Jacobs^^ George Eliot^^ p. 72).

Dublin Core:Title: Noble^^ Miss Henrietta
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Fairbrother's sister^^ a tiny^^ meek old lady with a benevolent disposition^^ who is very fond of Will Ladislaw.

Dublin Core:Title: Peacock^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lydgate's predecessor in Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Plessy^^ Lord
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A nobleman who lies in bed all day and plays at dominoes.

Dublin Core:Title: Plymdale^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A wealthy manufacturer and prominent citizen of Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Plymdale^^ Ned
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Son of Mr. and Mrs. Plymdale^^ and a rejected lover of Rosamond Vincy; "one of the good matches in Middlemarch^^ though not one of its leading minds."

Dublin Core:Title: Plymdale^^ Mrs. Selina
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The manufacturer's well-meaning wife; Mrs. Bulstrode's intimate friend.

Dublin Core:Title: Poincon^^ Madame
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A strict acquaintance of the Brooke sisters.

Dublin Core:Title: Powderell^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A retired ironmonger of Middlemarch^^ a man of some standing.

Dublin Core:Title: Powderell^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The ironmonger's wife^^ who privately takes Widgeon's Purifying Pills when she is under Lydgate's care.

Dublin Core:Title: Raffles^^ John
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Rigg Featherstone's stepfather; a dissipated bully who had been associated with Mr. Bulstrode in his dishonourable transactions. "He was a man obviously on the way towards sixty^^ very florid and hairy^^ with much grey in his bushy whiskers and thick curly hair^^ a stoutish body which showed to disadvantage the somewhat worn joinings of hie clothes^^ and the air of a swaggerer." Discovering Mr. Buletrode's whereabouts^^ he threatens to disclose the dishonesty of Bulstrode's early life^^ and is bribed to keep silence. At last he comes to Mr. Bulstrode at Stone Court ill and worn out from dissipation. Mr. Bulstrode^^ desiring his death^^ allows the doctor's orders to be disobeyed^^ and Raffles dies^^ but his death does not save Mr. Bulstrode^^ for Raffles had previously told the story of Mr. Bulstrode's dishonesty.

Dublin Core:Title: Renfrew^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A colonel's widow; guest at a dinner party given by Mr. Brooke.

Dublin Core:Title: Robisson^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Abel's former master.

Dublin Core:Title: Spanning^^ Dr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An acquaintance of Mr. Casaubon.

Dublin Core:Title: Spicer^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Shoemaker and parish clerk at Lowick.

Dublin Core:Title: Spilkins^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A young man reckless with his pocket-money.

Dublin Core:Title: Sprague^^ Dr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The senior physician of Middlemarch^^ a hard-headed and dry-witted man who is averse to Lydgate and his newer ideas. "The doctor was more than suspected of having no religion^^ but somehow Middlemarch tolerated this deficiency in him as if he had been a lord chancellor; indeed^^ it is probable that his professional weight was the more believed in^^ the world-old association of cleverness with the evil principle being still potent in the minds even of lady patients who had the strictest ideas of frilling and sentiment . . . Dr. Sprague was superfluously tall; his trousers got creased at the knees^^ and showed an excess of boot at a time when straps seemed necessary to any dignity of bearing; you heard him go in and out^^ and up and down^^ as if he had come to see after the roofing. In short^^ he had weight^^ and might be expected to grapple with a disease and throw it."

Dublin Core:Title: Sprague^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The doctor's wife "elderly and old-fashioned in her opinions"; one of the women who sit in judgment on Mrs. Bulstrode.

Dublin Core:Title: Standish^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyer in Middlemarch^^ a prosperous old man^^ "long concerned with the landed gentry^^" who had drawn up three wills for Mr. Featherstone. "Mr. Standish was not aman who varied his manners; he behaved with the same deepvoiced^^ off-hand civility to every body^^ as if he saw no difference in them^^ and talked chiefly of the hay crop^^ which would be 'Very fine^^ by God!' of the last bulletins concerning the King^^ and of the Duke of Clarence^^ who was a sailor every inch of him."

Dublin Core:Title: Strype^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Washerwoman^^ befriended by Mr. Bulstrode.

Dublin Core:Title: Taft^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An inhabitant of Middlemarch devoted to knitting.

Dublin Core:Title: Tapir^^ Lord
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A weak-minded young man.

Dublin Core:Title: Teveroy^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lord Grinsell's second wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Thesiger^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The rector's wife. "A small blinking woman^^ who fidgeted incessantly with her lace^^ ribbons^^ and gold chain^^ turning her head about and making subdued noises^^ very much like a guinea-pig^^ that twitches its nose and soliloquizes in all company indiscrimina

Dublin Core:Title: Thesiger^^ Reverend Edward
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Rector of St. Peter's^^ Middlemarch^^ a moderate evangelical^^ "who never goes into extremes."

Dublin Core:Title: Toller^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A long-established medical practitioner in Middlemarch who disapproves of Dr. Lydgate^^ and is hostile to Mr. Bulstrode. "Mr. Toller shared the highest practice in the town^^ and belonged to an old Middlemarch family . . . he had the easiest way in the world of taking things which might be supposed to annoy him^^ being a well-bred quietly facetious man^^ who kept a good house^^ was very fond of a little sporting when he could get it . . . It may seem odd that with such pleasant habits he should have been given to the heroic treatment^^ bleeding^^ and blistering and starving his patients^^ with a dispassionate disregard to his personal example."

Dublin Core:Title: Toller^^ Mr. Harry
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Brewer^^ a wealthy citizen of Middlemarch.

Dublin Core:Title: Toller^^ Miss Sophy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The brewer's daughter who marries Ned Plymdale.

Dublin Core:Title: Toller^^ Mrs. Tom
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of the guests at Mrs. Hackbutt's small tea party^^ where Mrs. Bulstrode is discussed.

Dublin Core:Title: Top Market^^ Middlemarch
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Top Market^^ Middlemarch

Dublin Core:Title: Triton^^ Lord
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A philanthropist^^ an acquaintance of Mrs. Cadwallader.

Dublin Core:Title: Truberry^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Wife of the above; an acquaintance of the Dowager Lady Chettam.

Dublin Core:Title: Trumbull^^ Mr. Borthrop
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Auctioneer; second cousin to Peter Featherstone^^ who bequeathes him his gold-headed cane. "Mr. Borthrop Trumbull^^ a distinguished bachelor and auctioneer of those parts^^ much concerned in the sale of land and cattle; a public character^^ indeed^^ whose name was seen on widely distributed placards^^ and who might reasonably be sorry for those who did not know of him . . . There was no odious cupidity in Mr. Borthrop Trumbull—nothing more than a sincere sense of his own merit . . . On the whole^^ in an auctioneering way^^ he was an honourable man^^ not ashamed of his business.

Dublin Core:Title: Tucker^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Casaubon's middle-aged curate. "Mr. Tucker . . . Was just as old and musty looking as she would have expected Mr. Casaubon's curate to be; doubtless an excellent man who would go to heaven (for Celia wished not to be unprincipled)^^ but the corners of his mouth were so unpleasant."

Dublin Core:Title: Tyke^^ Rev. Walter
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Curate in Middlemarch; a zealous man whose sermons are not popular and who is suspected of cant. Mr. Bulstrode favours him as Chaplain to the Infirmary and^^ with the assistance of Lydgate's vote^^ he is elected instead of Mr. Farebrother.

Dublin Core:Title: Vigo^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An acquaintance of the Dowager Lady Chettam^^ an irreproachable woman who is proposed as a companion to Mrs. Casaubon.

Dublin Core:Title: Vincy^^ Bob
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Younger son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincy.

Dublin Core:Title: Vincy^^ Fred
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincy; a good-looking young man with an irrepressibly hopeful disposition who chooses farming instead of the Church for which he had been educated. "Fred disliked bad weather within doors. He was too filial to be disrespectful to his father ... it was disagreeable ... to be obliged to look sulky instead of having fun; for Fred was so goodtempered that if he looked glum under scolding it was chiefly for propriety's sake . . . Fred piqued himself on keeping clear of lies^^ and even fibs . . . and rather than incur the accusation of falsehood he would even incur some trouble and self-restraint . . . Fred was not at all coarse ... he rather looked down on the manners and speech of young men who had not been to the university. A favourite of his uncle^^ the rich Mr. Featherstone^^ he is regarded by himself and his family as the old man's heir^^ and he looks forward to an easy^^ pleasant life. When his uncle dies^^ leaving his money to a natural son^^ Fred receives nothing and finds it necessary to decide what he is to make of himself^^ as his father cannot support him in idleness. Since childhood he has loved Mary Garth^^ and it is mainly through her influence that he disappoints his family and gives up the Church^^ for which he has been educated. Through Fred's thoughtlessness Mr. Garth loses money which he can ill afford to spare^^ but in spite of that^^ for Mary's sake^^ takes Fred into his office as his assistant^^ and Fred applies himself to his new work in the hope of winning Mary. His generous rival^^ Mr. Farebrother^^ helps him at a critical period. Later he is made manager of Stone Court^^ the property which he had once expected to inherit^^ and he then marries Mary and becomes a successful and happy farmer^^ very steady and devoted to his wife and sons

Dublin Core:Title: Vincy^^ Louisa
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Little daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincy.

Dublin Core:Title: Vincy^^ Mrs. Lucy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The mayor's handsome^^ good-humoured wife^^ who sees no fault in her children; an innkeeper's daughter. "She resigned no domestic function to her daughter; and the matron's blooming good-natured face^^ with the too volatile pink strings floating from her fine throat^^ and her cheery manners to husband and children was certainly among the great attractions of the Vincy house . . . The tinge of unpretentious^^ in offensive vulgarity in Mrs. Vincy gave more effect to Rosamond's refinement."

Dublin Core:Title: Vincy^^ Rosamond
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The mayor's beautiful daughter^^ later Lydgate's wife. "Rosamond Vincy^^ who had excellent taste in costume^^ with that nymph-like figure and pure blondeness which give the largest range to choice in the flow and color of drapery. But these things made only part of her charm. She was admitted to be the flower of Mrs. Lemon's school . . . Mrs. Lemon herself had always held up Miss Vincy as an example; no pupil^^ she said^^ exceeded that young lady for mental acquisition^^ and propriety of speech^^ while her musical execution was quite exceptional." "Rosamond was not one of those helpless girls who betray themselves unawares^^ and whose behavior is awkwardly driven by their impulses^^ instead of being steered by wary grace and propriety . . . Rosamond never showed any unbecoming knowledge^^ and was always that combination of correct sentiments^^ music^^ dancing^^ drawing^^ elegant note-writing^^ private album for extracted verse^^ and perfect blonde loveliness^^ which made the irresistible woman for the doomed man of that date . . . She was not in the habit of devising falsehoods^^ and if her statements were no direct clew to fact^^ why^^ they were not intended in that light— they were among her elegant accomplishments^^ intended to please. Nature had inspired many arts in finishing Mrs. Lemon's favourite pupil^^ who by general consent (Fred's excepted) was a rare compound of beauty^^ cleverness^^ and amiability." She holds herself above the young men of Middlemarch^^ but is attracted by Dr. Lydgate's superior breeding and connexions^^ falls as much in love with him as her self-centred nature will permit^^ and marries him without having the slightest understanding of his nobility of character and mind^^ and with no sympathy with his high aims in his profession. Worldly success measured in terms of income and social prestige is the only ambition which she can understand; she demands to be kept in luxury^^ refuses to yield to any of Lydgate's wishes^^ and to all of his attempts to explain to her his needs and his professional aims she opposes a gentle^^ inflexible obstinacy before which he is helpless. In the end he has to sacrifice his high ideals and scientific ambition and move to London in order to make the money necessary to give her the social position she craves. She never understands the ruin which she has made of his life^^ and continues to regard him as a person of mistaken ideas who needs the balance of her common sense.

Dublin Core:Title: Vincy^^ Mr. Walter
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mayor of Middlemarch; a manufacturer^^ a jolly^^ easy-going man^^ much given to hospitality and easily ruled by his wife and daughter. "Apart from his dinners and his coursing^^ Mr. Vincy^^ blustering as he was^^ had as little of his own way as if he had been a prime minister; the force of cir cumstances was easily too much for him^^ as it is for most pleasureloving florid men.

Dublin Core:Title: Waule^^ Elizabeth^^ Joanna^^ and Rebecca
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Waule's daughters; "all dark and ugly."

Dublin Core:Title: Waule^^ Mrs. Jane
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Featherstone's rich sister; a disagreeable^^ greedy woman^^ anxious for her brother's money.

Dublin Core:Title: Waule^^ John
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Son of Mrs. Waule; a bore.

Dublin Core:Title: Willoughby^^ Miss
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A schoolmate of Rosamond Vincy's.

Dublin Core:Title: Wimple^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Dr. Minchin's patients.

Dublin Core:Title: Wrench^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Medical attendant to the Vincy family; an irritable man^^ who shows great hostility to Lydgate after the latter replaces him in the Vincy family. "Mr. Wrench was a small^^ neat^^ bilious man^^ with a well-dressed wig; he had a laborious practice^^ and irascible temper^^ a lymphatic wife^^ and seven children."

Dublin Core:Title: Betty
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The Dempster's middle-aged cook.

Dublin Core:Title: Gower Street (Real)

Dublin Core:Description: Gower Street (Real)^^The street in London where Mr. Tryan found Lucy lying dead. A street in the Bloomsbury section of London running north from Bedfore Square.

Dublin Core:Title: "Soldier's Tear" (Real)

Dublin Core:Description: One of the songs sung by Miss Rebecca Linnet. Written by Thomas Haynes Bayly (1797-1839).

Dublin Core:Description: Bridge Way^^Street in Milby where Mr. Dempster meets with a fatal accident. "One of those dismal wide streets where dirt and misery have no long shadows thrown on them to soften their ugliness."

Dublin Core:Title: Dingley
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Dingley^^Parish near Milby.

Dublin Core:Description: Dog Lane^^Street in Milby.

Dublin Core:Description: Elmstoke Rectory^^Residence of Mr. Prendergast.

Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Friar's Gate^^The "Focus of the aristocracy" in Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Laxeter

Dublin Core:Description: Laxeter^^Town where Mr. Tryan had formerly held a curacy.

Dublin Core:Title: Gowes Street
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Gowes Street

Dublin Core:Title: Milby Church
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Milby Church^^The original of Milby Church is the parish church of St. Nicholas^^ at Nuneaton.

Dublin Core:Title: Orchard Street
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Orchard Street^^The Milby street in which the Dempsters' house is situated^^ and the scene of the Sunday evening demonstration against Mr. Tryan. "Orchard Street^^ which opened on the prettiest outskirt of the town--the church^^ the parsonage^^ and a long stretch of green fields." Church Street^^ Nuneaton^^ is the original of Orchard Street^^ Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Paddiford Church
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Paddiford Church^^The little Chapel-of-ease on Paddiford Common^^ of which Mr. Tryan is curate.

Dublin Core:Title: Paddiford Common
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Paddiford Common^^A poor district in Milby^^ the scene of the Reverend Mr. Tryan's labour. "Paddiford Common . . . was hardly recognizable as a common at all^^ but was a dismal district where you heard the rattle of the handloom^^ and breathed the smoke of the coal-pits." The original of Paddiford Common is Stockingford^^ between Nuneaton and Arbury.

Dublin Core:Title: Paddiford Lending Library
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Paddiford Lending Library

Dublin Core:Title: Pye's Croft
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Pye's Croft^^The place out of which Mrs. Linnet thinks Lawyer Dempster cheated her.

Dublin Core:Title: Salem Chapel
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Salem Chapel^^The Independent chapel in Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Thurston
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Thurston^^Town.

Dublin Core:Title: Tilston
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Tilston^^Place where Mr. Jerome used to live.

Dublin Core:Title: White House
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: White House^^Home of the Jeromes in Milby. "The garden was one of those old-fashioned paradises which hardly exist any longer except as memories of our childhood: no finical separation between flower and kitchen garden there; no monotony of enjoyment for one sense to the exclusion of another; but a charming paradisiacal mingling of all that was pleasant to the eyes and good for food."

Dublin Core:Title: Whitlow
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Whitlow^^Town near Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Job
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Kitty's "follyer".

Dublin Core:Title: Lakins
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Poor family in Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Lizzie
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Jerome's little granddaughter.

Dublin Core:Title: Trower
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Lawyer Dempster's clients.

Dublin Core:Subject: Item

Dublin Core:Title: "Bear and Ragged Staff"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Bear and Ragged Staff"^^Public house in Milby. As the scene of the story is laid in Warwickshire^^ the name of this inn is one of the touches of local colour^^ a bear and ragged staff being the coat of arms of the Earls of Warwick.

Dublin Core:Title: "Green Man"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Green Man"^^Public-house in Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: "Holly Mount"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Holly Mount"^^The house in which Janet Dempster settles Mrs. Pettifer so that Mr. Tryan may have a comfortable home.

Dublin Core:Title: "Red Lion"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Red Lion"^^Inn at Milby^^ frequented by Lawyer Dempster and his cronies. It is generally admitted that the original of the "Red Lion"^^ Milby^^ was the quaint old "Bull Hotel"^^ in Nuneaton.

Dublin Core:Title: "Two Travellers"
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Two Travellers"^^Public-house at Milby.

Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Item Type Metadata:Text: Boots^^ of the Red Lion^^ Milby

Dublin Core:Title: Dawes
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Dempster's man.

Dublin Core:Title: Kitty
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The Dempster's housemaid.

Dublin Core:Title: Lucy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The girl whose life Mr. Tryan “ruined” in his college days.

Dublin Core:Title: Phoebe
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Pettifer's servant.

Dublin Core:Title: Sally
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Jerome's servant.

Dublin Core:Title: Beale^^ Molly
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "A brawny old virago."

Dublin Core:Title: Bishop^^ The
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "The Bishop was an old man^^ and probably venerable (for though was not an eminent Grecian^^ he was the brother of a Whig lord)."

Dublin Core:Title: Brinley^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Carpenter's wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Budd^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Churchwarden at Milby; a satellite of Lawyer Dempster's. "Mr. Budd was a small^^ sleekheaded bachelor of five and forty^^ whose scandalous life had long furnished his more moral neighbours with an after-dinner joke. He had no other striking characteristic^^ except that he was a currier of choleric temperament^^ so that you might wonder why he had been chosen as clergyman's churchwarden^^ if I did not tell you that he had recently been elected through Mr. Dempster's exertions^^ in order that his zeal against the threatened evening lecture might be backed by the dignity of office." The original of Mr. Budd was said to have been a Mr. Burton.

Dublin Core:Title: Butcher's Lane^^ Milby
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Butcher's Lane^^ Milby

Dublin Core:Title: Byles^^ Mr. Luke
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An inhabitant of Milby^^ "who piqued himself on his reading and was in the habit of asking casual acquaintances if they knew anything of Hobbes." Mr Byles' original was a Tom Payne.

Dublin Core:Title: Caleb^^ Silly
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An idiot.

Dublin Core:Title: Coo^^ Phib
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An inhabitant of Bridge Way^^ Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Crewe^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The inefficient old curate at Milby. "There was almost always something funny about old Mr. Crewe. His brown wig was hardly ever put on quite right^^ and he had a way of raising his voice for three or four words^^ and lowering it againt to a mumble… It was clear he must be a learned man^^ for he had once had a large private school in connection with the grammar school^^ and had even numbered a young nobleman or two among his pupils. The fact that he read nothing at all now^^ and that his mind seemed absorbed in the commonest matters^^ was doubtless due to his having exhausted the resources of erudition earlier in life." In the lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life^^ the prototype of Mr. Crewe was the Rev. Hugh Hughes^^ (d. 1830)^^ for 52 years curate of Nuneaton and for 30 years head master of the Grammar School. He married Sarah Warden.

Dublin Core:Title: Crewe^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The curate's wife; a little^^ deaf old lady^^ who "would carry half her own spare dinner to the sick and hungry."

Dublin Core:Title: Dempster^^ Old Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyer Dempster's mother; a quiet^^ meek old lady who always believed that her son would not have gone wrong if he had married the right woman. "A very little old lady she was^^ with a pale^^ scarcely wrinkled face^^ hair of that peculiar white which tells that the locks have once been blond^^ a natty pure white cap on her head^^ and a white shawl pinned over her shoulders. You saw at a glance that she had been a mignonne blonde."

Dublin Core:Title: Dempster^^ Mrs. Janet
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The lawyer's unhappy wife; a woman of noble beauty^^ marked by traces of suffering. "Her grandly-cut features^^ pale with the natural paleness of a brunette^^ have premature lines about them telling that the years have been lengthened by sorrow^^ and the delicately-curved nostril^^ which seems made to quiver^^ with the proud consciousness of power and beauty^^ must have quivered to the heart-piercing griefs which have given that worn look to the corners of the mouth." "No other woman in Milby has those searching black eyes^^ that tall graceful unconstrained figure^^ set off by her simple mualin dress and black lace shawl^^ that massy black hair now so neatly braided in glossy contrast with the white satin ribbons of her modest cap and bonnet. No other woman has that sweet speaking smile." She had married Mr. Dempster for love buy^^ after much illtreatment^^ had yielded to the temptation to dull her suffering by drinking. As a climax to her unhappiness^^ her husband turns her out of the house in her nightgown at midnight. To please her husband she had joined in his persecution of Mr. Tryan^^ but in desperation she turns to that clergyman and his influence rescues her from her self-despair and gives her faith and strength to reform and lead a noble life. The original of Janet Dempster was a Mrs. Buchanan (Nancy Wallington) whose story^^ similar to Janet's as far as the treatment by her husband was concerned^^ was well known in Nuneaton when George Eliot lived there. Her grave and those of her husband and mother can still be seen at Nuneaton. (See references under Dempster^^ Robert.)

Dublin Core:Title: Dempster^^ Mr. Robert
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyer in Milby; a prosperoud^^ overbearing and unscrupulous man who is brutal toward his beautiful wife and intolerant toward Mr. Tryan. "He was a tall and rather massive man^^ and the front half of his large surface was… well dredged with snuff…. Mr. Dempster habitually held his chin tucked in^^ and his head hanging forward^^ weighed down^^ perhaps^^ by a preponderant occiput and a bulging forehead^^ between which his closely-clipped coronal surface lay like a flat and new-mown table-land. The only other observable features were puffy cheeks and a protruding yet lipless mouth. Of his nose I can only say that it saw snuffy^^ and as Mr. Dempster was never caught in the act of looking at anything in particular it would have been difficult to swear to the colour of his eyes." Although a man of much native ability^^ he yields more and more to his evil propensities^^ and beats his wife when he is drunk. He is the mainstay of the persecution of Mr. Tryan^^ turns his wife^^ Janet^^ out of the house at midnight and shortly after is thrown from his cart^^ receiving injuries which result in his death in delirium tremens. The original of Robert Dempster was a Mr. J. W. Buchanan^^ a lawyer of Nuneaton. The original of the Dempster house in "Orchard Street" still stands in Church Street^^ Nuneaton. (Manuscript and personal information; also Andrews^^ Bygone Warwickshire^^ p. 275; Browning^^ Life of George Eliot^^ pp. 52-3.)

Dublin Core:Title: Dunn^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Draper in Milby; an adherent of Mr. Tryan's.

Dublin Core:Title: Dunn^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The draper's wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Dunn^^ Mary
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The draper's daughter^^ a rather unattractive young girl.

Dublin Core:Title: Gardner^^ Maria
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A Milby girl who "had a lovely 'crop' of dark brown ringlets."

Dublin Core:Title: Gruby^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Grocer in Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: High Street^^ Milby
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: High Street^^ Milby

Dublin Core:Title: Horner^^ Reverend Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An Independent minister at Milby who^^ "elected with brilliant hopes^^ was discovered to be given to tippling and quarreling with his wife."

Dublin Core:Title: Jerome^^ Mrs. Susan
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Thomas Jerome's handsome wife^^ who is not always in sympathy with her husband's benvolent plans. "Mrs. Jerome was like her china^^ handsome and old-fashioned. She was a buxom lady of sixty^^ in an elaborate lace cap fastened by a frill under her chin^^ a dark^^ well-curled front concealing her forehead^^ a snowyneckerchief exhibiting its ample folds as far as her waist^^ and a stiff grey silk gown.

Dublin Core:Title: Jerome^^ Mr. Thomas
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A retired corn-factor of Milby^^ a benevolent Dissenter^^ and one of Mr. Tryan's firm supporters. "If you had heard the tone of mingled good-will^^ veneration^^ and condolence in which this greeting was uttered^^ even without seeing the face that completely har monized with it^^ you would have no difficulty in inferring the ground-notes of Mr. Jerome's character. To a fine ear that tone said as plainly as possible—'Whatever recommends itself to me^^ Thomas Jerome^^ as piety and goodness^^ shall have my love and honour. Ah^^ friends^^ this pleasant world is a sad one^^ too^^ isn't it? Let us help one another^^ let us help one another.' And it was entirely owing to this basis of character^^ not at all from any clear and precise doctrinal discrimination^^ that Mr. Jerome had very early in life become a Dissenter. In his boyish days he had been thrown where Dissent seemed to have the balance of piety^^ purity^^ and good works on its side^^ and to become a Dissenter seemed to him identical with choosing God instead of mammon." The lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life^^ the original of Mr. Jerome was given as a Mr. Everard. (See Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ p. 16.)

Dublin Core:Title: Lamb^^ Jonathan
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The old parish clerk in Milby. In the lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton after the publication of the Scenes of Clerical Life^^ a Mr. Wheway was given as the original of Jonathan Lamb. (See Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ p. 16.)

Dublin Core:Title: Landor^^ Miss
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The belle of Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Landor^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Banker in Milby; one of Mr. Tryan's supporters. The original of Mr. Landor was a Mr. Craddock. (Manuscript information; also Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ p. 16.)

Dublin Core:Title: Landor^^ Mr. Eustace
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A young dandy in Milby^^ the banker's son.

Dublin Core:Title: Linnet^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A matter-of-fact^^ rather vulgar widow; a member of Mr. Tryan's congregation.

Dublin Core:Title: Linnet^^ Miss Mary
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Linnet's elder daughter^^ an amiable^^ colourless woman past her first youth^^ who is in love with Mr. Tryan. "She had always combined a love of serious and poetical reading with her skill in fancywork^^ and the neatly-bound copies of Dryden's Virgil^^ Hannah More's Sacred Dramas^^ Falconer's Shipwreck^^ Mason On Self-Knowledge^^ Rasselas^^ and Burke On the Sublime and Beautiful^^ which were the chief ornaments of the book-case . . . had been bought with her pocket-money when she was in her teens . . . Miss Linnet had dark ringlets^^ a sallow complexion^^ and an amiable disposition. As to her features^^ there was not much to criticize in them^^ for she had little nose^^ less lip^^ and no eye brow; and as to her intellect^^ her friend Mrs. Pettifer often said: 'She didn't know a more sensible person to talk to than Mary Linnet' . . . While most peopJe thought it a pity that a sensible woman like Mary had not found a good husband." In the lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton after he publication of Scenes of Clerical Life^^ the originals of the Misses Linnet were the Misses Hill. Mrs. Linnet was Mrs. Hill. (Manuscript notes.)

Dublin Core:Title: Linnet^^ Miss Rebecca
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Linnet's younger daughter^^ a headstrong^^ unpopular woman. Like her sister^^ she is in love with Mr. Tryan^^ for whose sake she gives up finery. "Rebecca was always spoken of sarcastically^^ and it was a customary kind of banter with young ladies to recommend her as a wife to any gentleman they happened to be flirting with—her fat^^ her finery^^ and her thick ankles sufficing to give piquancy to the joke^^ notwithstanding the absence of novelty."

Dublin Core:Title: Lowme^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An elderly man in Milby who prides himself on his aristocracy. "Mr. Lowme^^ one of the most aristocratic men in Milby^^ said to have been 'brough up a gentleman'^^ and to have had the gay habits accordant with that station^^ keeping his harriers and other expensive animals. He was now quite an elderly Lothario^^ reduced to the most economical sins; the prominent form of his gaiety being this of lounging at Mr. Gruby's door^^ embarrassing the servant-maids who came for grocery^^ and talking scandal with the rare passers-by." In the lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life^^ the original of Mr. Lowme is said to have been a Mr. Towle. (See Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ p. 16.)

Dublin Core:Title: Lowme^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Lowme's wife^^ a firm believer in Mr. Pilgrim's skill.

Dublin Core:Title: Lowme^^ Mr. Bob
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The possessor of beautiful whiskers which meet under his chin.

Dublin Core:Title: Madeley^^ Dr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Physician from Rotherby^^ called in to attend Milly Barton.

Dublin Core:Title: Marriott^^ Ellen
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A pretty Milby girl.

Dublin Core:Title: Martin^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Sally's mother.

Dublin Core:Title: Martin^^ Sally
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A deformed girl in Milby^^ befriended by Janet Dempster.

Dublin Core:Title: Mercer^^ Joseph
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An old man in Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Paine^^ Mat
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyer Dempster's clerk.

Dublin Core:Title: Pettifer^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Janet Dempster's kind friend who shelters her when her husband turns her out at midnight. "The small^^ elderly lady in dowdy clothing^^ who is also working diligently^^ is Mrs. Pettifer^^ a superior-minded widow^^ much valued in Milby^^ being such a very respectable person to have in the house in case of illness^^ and of quite too good a family to receive any money-payment — you could always send her garden-stuff that would make her ample amends." The original of Mrs. Pettifer was a Mrs. Robinson. (Manuscript information; also Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ p. 16; Coventry^^ Centenary^^ p. 5.)

Dublin Core:Title: Phipps^^ Miss
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A young lady fond of fine clothes.

Dublin Core:Title: Phipps^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Phipps's amiable husband. In the lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life the original of Mr. Phipps is given as a Mr. Bull. (See Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ p. 16.)

Dublin Core:Title: Phipps^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Mr. Pratt's chief patients in Milby; "a woman of decided opinions^^ though of wheezy utterance." The original of Mrs. Phipps was Mrs. Bull.

Dublin Core:Title: Phipps^^ Mr. Alfred
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A young Milby dandy.

Dublin Core:Title: Pittman^^ The Misses
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyer Pittman's four tall daughters^^ "with cannon curls surmounted by large hats^^ and long drooping ostrich feathers of parrot green."

Dublin Core:Title: Pittman^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An old lawyer in Milby^^ Mr. Dempster's partner. "No one in Milby considered old Pittman a virtuous man^^ and the elder townspeople were not at all backward in narrating the least advantageous portions of his biography in a very round unvarnished manner. Yet I could never observe that they trusted him any the less^^ or liked him any the worse." In the lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life a Mr. Greenway was given as the original of Mr. Pittman. (See Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ p. 16.)

Dublin Core:Title: Powers^^ Bill
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Leader of the beer drinkers at the "Bear and Ragged Staff".

Dublin Core:Title: Pratt^^ Miss
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The doctor's sister and housekeeper. "Miss Pratt was an old maid with a cap^^ a braided 'front'^^ a backbone and appendages. Miss Pratt was the one blue stocking of Milby^^ possessing^^ she said^^ no less than five hundred volumes^^ competent^^ as her brother the doctor often observed^^ to conduct a conversation on any topic whatever^^ and occasionally dabbling a little in authorship^^ though it was understood that she had never put forth the full powers of her mind in print.

Dublin Core:Title: Pratt^^ Miss Eliza
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The doctor's daughter; a handsome girl^^ somewhat in love with Mr. Tryan.

Dublin Core:Title: Pratt^^ Mr. Richard
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description:
Doctor; Mr. Pilgrim's rival in Milby^^ and an adherent of Mr. Tryan. "Pratt was middle-sized^^ insinuating^^ and silvery-voiced. . . . Pratt elegantly referred all diseases to debility^^ and^^ with a proper contempt for symptomatic treatment^^ went to the root of the matter with port wine and bark. . . . There was the most perfect unanimity between Pratt and
Pilgrim in the determination to drive away the obnoxious and too probably unqualified intruder as soon as possible . . . But by their respective patients these two distinguished men were pitted against each other with great virulence." The original of Mr. Pratt was a Mr. Bond. (See Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ p. 16.)

Dublin Core:Title: Prendergast^^ The Hon. And Rev. Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Non-resident rector of Milby. "Mr. Prendergast looked much more dignified with his plain white surplice and black hair. He was a tall commanding man^^ and read the Liturgy in a strikingly sonorous and uniform voice." The original of the Hon. and Rev. Mr. Prendergast was the Hon. and Rev. R. B. Stopford^^ vicar of Nuneaton. (See Olcott^^ George Eliot^^ pp. 16^^ 39.)
Dublin Core:Relation: Prendergast^^ The Hon. And Rev. Mr.

Dublin Core:Title: Procter^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Printer and stationer^^ who keeps a circulating library.

Dublin Core:Title: Pryme^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A client of Lawyer Dempster's with whom he quarrels.

Dublin Core:Title: Redhill Road^^ Milby
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Redhill Road^^ Milby

Dublin Core:Title: Ricketts^^ Dame
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An inhabitant of the Bridge Way^^ Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Rose^^ Reverend Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Independent minister who failed at Salem chapel because his doctrine was a little to "high".

Dublin Core:Title: Smith^^ Reverend Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Independent minister of the Salem Chapel^^ Milby^^ with a talent for poetry^^ who exchanges verses with the ladies of his congregation.

Dublin Core:Title: Stickney^^ Rev. Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Independent minister in Milby^^ who failed at the Salem Chapel.

Dublin Core:Title: Thomson^^ Liza
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Servant.

Dublin Core:Title: Thrupp^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Clerk at the Milby bank.

Dublin Core:Title: Tomlinson^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Rich miller at Milby; one of Lawyer Dempster's chief admirers. "Mr. Tomlinson . . . often said his father had given him 'no eddication^^ and he didn't care who knowed it; he could buy up most o' th' eddicated men he'd ever come across '." In the lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton^^ after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life^^ a Mr. Hinks was given as the original of Mr. Tomlinson. (See Olcoot^^ George Eliot^^ p. 16.)

Dublin Core:Title: Townley^^ Miss
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mistress of a girls' school in Milby.

Dublin Core:Title: Traunter^^ Deb
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A disreputable acquaintance of Mr. Budd.

Dublin Core:Title: Tryan^^ Miss
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The curate's sister.

Dublin Core:Title: Tryan^^ Reverend Edgar
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The evangelical curate at Paddiford Common^^ Milby^^ by whose in fluence Janet Dempster is rescued. "The strange light from the golden sky falling on his light brown hair^^ which is brushed high up round his head^^ makes it look almost like an aureole. His grey eyes^^ too^^ shine with unwonted brilliancy this evening. They were not remarkable eyes^^ but they accorded completely in their changing light with the changing expression of his person^^ which indicated the paradoxial character often observable in a large-limbed sanguine blond; at once mild and irritable^^ gentle and overbearing^^ indolent and resolute^^ self-con scious and dreamy." "But Mr. Tryan was not cast in the mould of the gratuitous martyr. With a power of persistence which had been often blamed as obstinacy^^ he had an acute sensibility to the very hatred or ridicule he did not flinch from provoking. Every form of disapproval jarred him painfully; and^^ though he fronted his opponents manfnlly^^ and often with considerable warmth of temper^^ he had no pugnacious pleasure in the contest. It was one of the weaknesses of his nature to be too keenly alive to every harsh wind of opinion." In his youth he had been wild^^ and the realization of his sins had caused him to enter the churoh and to devote his life to others. When he comes to Milby he has to struggle against the indifference of those whom he would help and the malevolent opposition of  Lawyer Dempster. In the end his sympathy^^ faith^^ and high purpose give him the victory^^ for which^^ however^^ he pays with his life. He dies happy in the knowledge that^^ through his influence^^ Janet Dempster has been rescued from despair. There was undoubtedly an original for the story of the persecution of Mr. Tryan. George Eliot^^ in 1857^^ said: "The story^^ as far as regards the persecution^^ is a real bit in the religious history of England that happened about eight and twenty years ago." The Reverend W. P. Jones wrote to William Blackwood that Mr. Tryan was drawn from his deceased brother but George Eliot disclaimed this^^ saying: "Mr. Tryan is not a portrait of any clergyman^^ living or dead." (See Cross^^ George Eliot's Life^^ vol.1^^ pp. 458^^ 462.)

Dublin Core:Title: Tucker's Lane^^ Milby
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Tucker's Lane^^ Milby

Dublin Core:Title: Wagstaff^^ Mrs.

Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Tryan's landlady^^ noted for her dingy house and dubious cookery.

Dublin Core:Title: Walsh^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The curate who succeeds Mr. Tryan at Paddiford Common.

Dublin Core:Title: Wright^^ Jacob
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A Dissenter who kepat at night school.

Dublin Core:Title: Bantam
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A small^^ feebly crowing individual who attempts to correct the brilliant Aquila.

Dublin Core:Title: Bombus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A loud buzzing^^ bouncing writer.

Dublin Core:Title: Bruin
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An epicure who found and tasted a honeycomb.

Dublin Core:Title: Butzkopf
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A German scholar.

Dublin Core:Title: Callista
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An imaginative person^^ who frequently gives false testimonials.

Dublin Core:Title: Corvus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An inconsistent person who takes a mild view of Mordax's fierceness when it is directed against someone else.

Dublin Core:Title: Crispi
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An artist^^ one of Scintilla's fashionable circle.

Dublin Core:Title: Dugong
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A German scholar.

Dublin Core:Title: Eocene Mines
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Sir Gavial Mantrap's swindling company

Dublin Core:Title: Ganymede
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An old-young writer^^ "once a girlishly handsome and precocious youth" who had produced a "Comparative estimate of European nations" before he was well out of his teens and continues to regard himself as wonderfully young when he is fat and middle-aged.

Dublin Core:Title: Gregarina
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A lady "whose distinction was that she had had cholera and who did not feel herself in her true position with strangers until they knew it."

Dublin Core:Title: Heloisa
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A lady who disapproves of Laura's attempts to disguise her age.

Dublin Core:Title: "Pulpit" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: Theophrastus Such's valet and factotum^^ "an excellent respectable servant whose spelling is unvitiated by non-phonetic superfluities: and who is never surprised.

Dublin Core:Title: Pumpiter
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Pumpiter^^"The considerable provincial town" where Vorticella^^ the authoress of one book^^ lives.

Dublin Core:Title: Megalosaurus
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: "Greatest of fossils."

Dublin Core:Title: Rosemary's "Babes in the Woods"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
Dublin Core:Description: "Something fresh and naïve in sculpture" of which Hinze asks Felicia's opinion.

Dublin Core:Title: Laura
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A lady disapproved of by Heloisa because she disguises her age.

Dublin Core:Title: Loligo
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A fluent writer^^ in the great Merman-Grampus controversy.

Dublin Core:Title: Magicodumbras
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A subject about which Proteus Merman discovers the great Grampus to be all wrong.

Dublin Core:Title: Melissa
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A sentimental lady who pities the swindler^^ Sir Gavial Mantrap^^ because he "is an excellent family man".

Dublin Core:Title: Microps
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A "Cetacean of unanswerable authority".

Dublin Core:Title: Pepin
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The too ready writer; a busy "general writer" who feels a "certain surprise that there have not been more persons equal to himself".

Dublin Core:Title: Semper
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A poor speaker who makes many public speeches.

Dublin Core:Title: Spike
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "A political molecule" who voted on the side of Progress though he was not inwardly attached to it under that name.

Dublin Core:Title: Theron
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A painstaking student whose condensed exposition is excluded to leave space for the copious brew of Adrastus^^ the too-ready writer.

Dublin Core:Title: Trost
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An optimist who believes that at some future period this will be the best of all possible worlds^^ and who does not agree with Theophrastus Such about the future of the human race.

Dublin Core:Title: Ubique
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A public speaker who is criticized by Seemper for the very faults which Semper possesses.

Dublin Core:Title: Ziphius
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A Cetacean of unanswerable authority^^ whom Mr. Merman finds to be at issue with the great Grampus.

Dublin Core:Title: Zuzumotzis
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A subject of research on which Mr. Merman finds the great Grampus in error.

Dublin Core:Title: Avis
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A man giving to "saccharine excesses."

Dublin Core:Title: Bovis
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A gentleman who is horrified at the saccharine excesses of Avis^^ not realizing that he himself takes twenty-six lumps of sugar each day.

Dublin Core:Title: Euphorion
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A plagiarist who freely ackowledges the source of his ideas when the citation of great names of the past will show his scholarship^^ but who passes off other borrowing as his own^^ and "is disposed to treat the distinction between mine and thine in original authorship as egoistic^^ narrowing^^ and low".

Dublin Core:Title: Felicia
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A clever woman whose opinion are eagerly sought by Mr. Hintze^^ the too deferential man.

Dublin Core:Title: Hautboy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Quoted by Hintze^^ the too deferential man^^ as regarding Chaucer as a poet of the first order.

Dublin Core:Title: Hinze
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "The too deferential man." "He is the superlatively deferential man^^ and walks about with murmured wonder at the wisdom and discernment of everybody who talks to him. He cultivates the low toned tete-a-teta^^ keeping his hat carefully in his hand and often stroking it^^ while he smiles with downcast eyes as if to relieve his feelings under the pressure of the remarkable conversation which it is his honour to enjoy."

Dublin Core:Title: Laniger
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A man with "a temper but no talent for repartee"^^ who is persuaded that his harsh critic Mordax is a wolf at heart.

Dublin Core:Title: Lentulus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A conceited man^^ "surprised at his own originality^^" who is reserved in praising his contemporaries because he sees how superior his own work on the same lines would have been if he had ever taking it up.

Dublin Core:Title: Lippus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A blunderer^^ who ruins his chance by a too elaborate personal canvas.

Dublin Core:Title: Mixtus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A successful business man who has gained great wealth but finds the spiritual and intellectual interests and ideals of his youth submerged in the society which his lively and worldly wife collects around her.

Dublin Core:Title: Monas
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The author of a single book^^ entitled Here and There^^ or A Trip from Truro and Transylvania.

Dublin Core:Title: Mordax
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "The watch dog of knowledge^^" an intellectual worker who is admirable and kindly in his personal relations^^ but a biting critic and fierce antagonist if he is corrected or his opinions challenged.

Dublin Core:Title: Scintilla
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mixtus's worldly wife^^ a lively lady who knows nothing of Nonconformists except that they are unfashionable^^ and who cuts her husband off from his old friends and ideals.

Dublin Core:Title: Touchwood
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A bad-tempered man. "He is by turns insolent^^ quarrelsome^^ repulsively haughty to innocent people who approach him with respect^^ neglectful of his friends^^ angry in face of legitimate demands^^ procrastinat ing in the fulfilment of such demands^^ prompted to rude words and harsh looks by a moody disgust with his fellow men in general—and yet^^ as everybody will assure you^^ the s0ul of honour^^ a steadfast friend^^ a defender of the oppressed^^ an affectionate hearted creature."

Dublin Core:Title: Tulpian
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A gentleman with considerable interest at his disposal to whom Hinze^^ the too deferential man^^ frequently speaks.

Dublin Core:Title: Vibrio
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The critic who writes in the Medley Pie praising Vorticella's book.

Dublin Core:Title: Volvox
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The critic of the Monitor^^ who^^ according to Vorticella^^ contradicts himself in his review of her book.

Dublin Core:Title: Voritcella
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "A portly lady walking in silk attire^^" the authoress of a book entitled "The Channel Islands^^ with Notes and an Appendix"^^ which she allows no one to forget.

Dublin Core:Title: Bantam^^ Sir Hong Kong
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of Mixtus's fashionable acquaintances.

Dublin Core:Title: Barabbas^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A swindler whose morals are such a contrast to those of that excellent family man^^ Sir Gavial Mantrap.

Dublin Core:Title: Bovis^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Bovis's watchful wife^^ who counts his lumps of sugar.

Dublin Core:Title: Cachalot^^ Monsieur
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A French scholar^^ who comments on the Merman-Grampus dispute.

Dublin Core:Title: Catulus^^ S.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A younger member of Shark's remarkable family.

Dublin Core:Title: Fugleman^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A critic whose recent remarks about the Iliad Mr. Hintze cites.

Dublin Core:Title: Grampus^^ Greenland
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A great authority^^ author of an epoch-making book^^ whose theory about the Magicodumbras and the Zuzumotzis Proteus Merman discovers to be wrong.

Dublin Core:Title: Hoopoe^^ of John's
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A critic who thinks that Toucan of Magdalen is the author of a certain work.

Dublin Core:Title: Johns^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A Baptist minister with a solemn twang.

Dublin Core:Title: Mantrap^^ Sir Gavial
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A swindler who is excused and pitied by some^^ because he has such good morals.

Dublin Core:Title: Merman^^ Julia
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Proteus Merman's devoted wife^^ who is involved in his misfortunes.

Dublin Core:Title: Merman^^ Proteus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A young man of promise who discovers an error in the epoch-making work of Grampus; he is ruined by the resulting controversy^^ while Grampus annexes his idea and takes all the credit for himself.

Dublin Core:Title: Narwhal^^ Lord
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Grampus's friend.

Dublin Core:Title: Porpesse^^ M.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A French savant who takes notice of the great Merman-Grampus controversy.

Dublin Core:Title: Such^^ Theophrastus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An eccentric observer and humorist who analyses and comments upon the various types of people whom he meets in the "Nation of London". "Yet I am a bachelor^^ and the person I love best has never loved me^^ or known that I loved her. Though continually in society^^ and caring about the joys and sorrows of my neighbours^^ I feel myself^^ so far as my personal lot is concerned^^ uncared for and alone . . . Why should I expect to be admired ... I have done no services to my country beyond those of every peaceable orderly citizen; and as to intellectual contribution^^ my only published work was a failure so that I am spoken of to inquiring beholders as 'the author of a book you have probably not seen' . . . Then in some quarters my awkward feet are against me^^ the length of my upper lip^^ and an inveterate way I have of walking with my head foremost and my chin projecting."

Dublin Core:Title: Whale^^ Scrag
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An explorer; a Cetacean of unanswerable authority^^ whom Mr. Merman discovers to be at issue with Grampus.

Dublin Core:Title: Whale^^ Professer Sperm N
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A distinguished Cetacean from whose spirited article in an American newspaper Grampus first leanrs of Mr. Merman's book.

Dublin Core:Title: Batt and Cowley
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyers of the Bycliffes.

Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Gardener at Treby Manor.

Dublin Core:Title: Cock-Fighting Jack
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Name given to Mr. Lingon in older and less serious days.

Dublin Core:Title: Cowley
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Member of the legal firm of Batt & Cowley.

Dublin Core:Title: Dow
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Printer in Treby Magna.

Dublin Core:Title: Dredge
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Miner in Sproxton; "a big^^ red-whiskered man." He takes part in the election riot at Treby and is sentenced to a year's imprisonment.

Dublin Core:Title: Durfeys
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Ancestors of the Transomes of the time of Felix Holt^^ and cousins of the original Transomes; they came into possession of the Transome estate through purchase^^ and were then known as the Durfey-Transomes.

Dublin Core:Title: Dymick and Halliwell
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyers.

Dublin Core:Title: Gills
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Stone-cutter in Sproxton^^ "a wide-mouthed^^ wiry man."

Dublin Core:Title: Halliwell
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyer^^ of the firm of Dymock and Halliwell.

Dublin Core:Description: Bedford Row (Real)^^The street in London where Mr. Johnson lives. A street in Holborn^^ at the north end of Brownlow Street.

Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: "Belle Sauvage" (Real)^^London inn^^ where Annette Ledru goes with her baby^^ expecting to meet her husband.

Dublin Core:Description: Blackheath (Real)^^Henry Scaddon's birthplace. A suburb of London.

Dublin Core:Title: Glasgow (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Glasgow (Real)^^Place where Felix Holt had studies and where^^ for a while^^ he lived a wild life. Glasgow is the seat of the important University of Glasgow^^ founded 1451.

Dublin Core:Title: Smyrna (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Smyrna (Real)^^The Eastern city where Harold Transome had made his money. The principal seaport of Asiatic Turkey^^ an important commercial city.

Dublin Core:Title: Verdun (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Verdun (Real)^^One of the French towns in which Maurice Christian Bycliffe and Henry Scaddon had been prisoners. A fortress town in the departement of the Meuse^^ in the northeastern part of France.

Dublin Core:Title: Vesoul (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Vesoul (Real)^^The French town where Annette Ledru and Maurice Christian Bycliffe were married. Vesoul^^ capital of the departement of Haute-Saone.

Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: A tune which Felix Holt is whistling when he finds Christian's lost pocket-book. Bannockburn^^ or Scot's^^ wha hae wi' Wallace bled^^ a song by Robert Burns^^ set to the old Scotch tune called Hey tutti taitie.

Dublin Core:Title: "Evangelical Magazine" (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Name
Dublin Core:Description: The magazine which the Muscats took in. The Evangelical Magazine and Missionary Chronicle^^ London^^ first established 1793.

Dublin Core:Description: Hathercote^^Village near Treby.

Dublin Core:Description: Loamshire^^ North^^The section in England in which the Transome estates are situated; the scene of the novel Felix Holt.

Dublin Core:Title: Malthouse Yard
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Malthouse Yard^^The location of the Independent Chapel and of Mr. Lyon's house in Treby Magna. The original of Rufus Lyon's chapel in Malthouse Yard was Cow Lane Chapel^^ Coventry^^ where the Reverend Francis Franklin ("Rufus Lyon") preached for fifty four years. George Eliot went to this chapel when she was a studen in the Misses Franklin's school.

Dublin Core:Description: Pollard's End^^Section of Treby Magna.
