Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Pritchley^^District near Treby.

Dublin Core:Title: Rabbitt's End
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Rabbitt's End^^Farm on the Transome estate.

Dublin Core:Title: Skipper's Lane
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Skipper's Lane^^The location of Mr. Lyon's first meeting.

Dublin Core:Title: Sproxton
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Sproxton^^A mining hamlet near Treby Magna^^ where Felix Holt is in the habit of going to talk with the miners.

Dublin Core:Title: Transome Court
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Transome Court^^Home of the Transome family^^ near Treby Magna; "a place there had been a fine sight of lawsuits about."

Dublin Core:Title: Treby Magna
Dublin Core:Subject: Fictional Place
Dublin Core:Description: Treby Magna^^Town in North Loamshire; the home of Felix Holt and the Lyons and the scene of an election riot. "Treby Magna^^ on which the Reform Bill had thrust the new honour of being a polling-place^^ had been^^ at the beginning of the century^^ quite a typical old market-town^^ lying in pleasant sleepiness among green pastures^^ with a rush-fringed river meandering through them. Its principal street had various handsome and tall-windowed brick houses with walled gardens behind them; and at the end^^ where it widened into the market-place^^ there was the cheerful rough-stuccoed front of that excellent inn^^ the Marquis of Granby . . . And the church was one of those fine old English structures worth travelling to see^^ standing in a broad churchyard with a line of solemn yew-treesbeside it^^ and lifting a majestic tower and spire far above the redand-purple roofs of the town. . . Treby Magna gradually passed from being simply a respectable market-town—the heart of agreat rural district^^ where the trade was only such as had close relations with the local landed interest—and took on the more complex life brought by mines and manufactures." It has been suggested that in the original of Treby Magna was the ancient town of Coventry^^ in Warwickshire^^ where George Eliot lived for some time^^ but beyond the fact that there was a Coventry original for Rufus Lyon's chapel^^ there seems to be nothing to support this suggestion. (Manuscript information; also Dryden^^ Memorials of Old Warwickshire^^ p. 125; Muirhead^^ England^^ p. 326.)

Dublin Core:Title: Pitt^^ Mr. (Hist.)

Dublin Core:Title: "White Hart"

Dublin Core:Description: "White Hart"^^Inn at Loamford where Jermyn tells Harold Transome of their relationship.

Dublin Core:Title: Banks
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Bailiff at Transome Court.

Dublin Core:Title: Bylciffe versus Transome
Dublin Core:Subject: Event
Dublin Core:Description: Lawsuit instituted by Maurice Christian Bycliffe^^ Esther Lyon's father^^ to obtain possession of the Transome estate. John Justus Transome in 1729 had made a settlement of his estates entailing them on his son Thomas and his heirs-male^^ with remainder to the Bycliffes in fee. Thomas^^ a prodigal^^ had sold his own and his descendants' rights to a lawyer-cousin named Durfey^^ whose descendants^^ the Durfey-Transomes (the Transomes of the story)^^ are the rightful holders of the estate as long as there exists a male descendant of Thomas Transome. In the absence of such male descendant the right to the estate would pass to the Bycliffes. The complicated legal plot of the story rests upon this Durfey-Transome-Bycliffe situation and the fact that Esther Lyon's claim (as the last Bycliffe) becomes valid on the death of old Tommy Trounsem^^ the last descendant of Thomas Transome. In order to be sure that she was right in her handling of a plot based upon a question of law^^ George Eliot consulted Frederic Harrison^^ who suggested the legal scheme of the story and wrote the lawyer's "opinion on the case"^^ which was incorporated in the novel. Frederic Harrison said later: "I remember telling her^^ when she inserted these lines in the book^^ that I had written at least a sentence which was embodied in English literature." (See Harrison^^ Studies in Early Victorian Literature^^ p. 218; also his Memories and Thoughts^^ p. 137-140; also Cross^^ George Eliot's Life^^ vol. 2^^ p. 420^^ 423.)

Dublin Core:Title: Denner
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Transome's devoted maid; wife of Mr. Hicks the butler^^ but always called by her maiden name. "Denner's feeling towards her mistress… was of that worshipful sort paid to a goddess in ages when it was not thought necessary or likely that a goddess should be very moral... There was a tacit understanding that Denner knew all her mistress's secrets^^ and her speech was plain and unflattering; yet with wonderful subtlety of instinct she never said anything with Mrs. Transome could feel humiliated by... She was a hard-headed godless little woman^^ but with a character to be reckoned on as you reckon on the qualities of iron."

Dublin Core:Title: Dominic
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Harold Transome's man. "One of those wonderful southern fellows that make one's life easy. He's of no country in particular. I don't know whether he's most of a Jew^^ a Greek^^ an Italian^^ or a Spaniard. He speaks five or six languages^^ one as well as another. He's cook^^ valet^^ major-domo^^ and secretary all in one; and what's more^^ he's an affectionate fellow."

Dublin Core:Title: Hickes
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The old butler at Transome Court.

Dublin Core:Title: Jabez
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Footman at Transome Court.

Dublin Core:Title: Kitty
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Servant at Transome Court.

Dublin Core:Title: Letty
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Servant at Transome Court.

Dublin Core:Title: Lyddy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Lyon's old servant^^ much given to despondency and groans.

Dublin Core:Title: Thomas
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The Reverend Augustus Debarry's servant.

Dublin Core:Title: Bodkin^^ Brother
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A member of Mr. Lyon's congregation.

Dublin Core:Title: Brindle^^ Mike
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A head miner^^ whose real name is Michael Brincey; one of the witnesses for Felix Holt at his trial.

Dublin Core:Title: Button^^ Peggy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An inhabitant of Sproxton.

Dublin Core:Title: Bycliffe^^ Edward
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The ancestor of Esther Lyon^^ who lived at the time when the base-fee to the Transome estates was created.

Dublin Core:Title: Bycliffe^^ Maurice Christian
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The representative of the family which claimed the Transome estate; Esther Lyon's father. When a prisoner of war in France he had married Annette Ledru. By exchanging names with Henry Scaddon^^ a fellow-prisoner whose exchange had been effected^^ he was able to return to England^^ leaving his wife to follow him. In England he instituted a suit against the Transomes^^ believing that the estate was legally his. During the progress of the suit he had been imprisoned as Henry Scaddon^^ and had died in prison^^ before his wife and infant daughter could reach him.

Dublin Core:Title: Calibut^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A Tory who made his fortune in trade.

Dublin Core:Title: Cherry^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lady's maid at Treby Manor.

Dublin Core:Title: Christian^^ Maurice
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Assumed name of Henry Scaddon. A clever but not very successful adventurer. In his youth he had been wild^^ dissipating his fortune and committing forgery. Later he had been a fellow prisoner-of-war in France with Maurice Christian Bycliffe^^ and by exchanging names with him had helped Bycliffe to escape to England. He kept the name of Maurice Christian and much later enters the service of Philip Debarry^^ which brings him to Treby. There he sees Esther Lyon^^ learns from Mr. Lyon that she is Bycliffe's daughter^^ and then sells this information to Harold Transome.

Dublin Core:Title: Chubb^^ William
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Landlord of the Sugar Loaf^^ Sproxton^^ where Felix Holt goes to talk with the miners. "Mr. Chubb was a remarkable publican; none of your stock Bonifaces^^ red^^ bloated^^ jolly^^ and joking. He was thin and sallow^^ and was never^^ as his constant guests observed^^ seen to be the worse (or the better) for liquor... Mr. Chubb's reasons for becoming landlord of the Sugar Loaf were founded on the severest calculation. Having an active mind^^ and being averse to bodily labour^^ he had thoroughly considered what calling would yield him the best livelihood with the least possible exertion^^ and in that sort of line he had seen that a 'public' amongst miners who earned high wages was a fine opening."

Dublin Core:Title: Clement^^ Sir James
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The ministerial candidate for Parliament in North Loamshire^^ "a poor baronet^^ hoping for an appointment^^" who retires before the election.

Dublin Core:Title: Cozen^^ Mr. German
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Name given to Mr. Jermyn because of his clever shuffling.

Dublin Core:Title: Crow^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: High constable of Treby^^ an unpopular man who fails to quiet the Treby mob at the time of the election riot.

Dublin Core:Title: Crowder^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An old tenant of the Debarrys^^ "much in arrear as to his rent."

Dublin Core:Title: Cuff^^ Jacob
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A charity-man.

Dublin Core:Title: Debarry^^ Lady
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Wife of Sir Maximus. "A bule-eyed^^ well-featured lady^^ fat and middle-aged^^ a mountain of satin^^ lace^^ and exquisite muslin embroidery."

Dublin Core:Title: Debarry^^ Rev^^ Augustus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Rector of Treby Magna; brother of Sir Maximus. "A fine specimen of the old-fashioned aristocratic clergyman^^ preaching short sermons^^ understanding business^^ and acting liberally about his tithe."

Dublin Core:Title: Debarry^^ Harriet
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of the elegant daughters of Sir Maximus and Lady Debarry.

Dublin Core:Title: Debarry^^ Sir Maximus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The head of the leading family in Treby Magna; an open-handed^^ quick-tempered man of sixty. An aristocratic old Tory^^ he is prepared to welcome Harold Transome cordially until he finds that the latter has declared himself a Radical. He does not resume friendly relations with Harold until the scene of Mr. Jermyn's revelation to Harold.

Dublin Core:Title: Debarry^^ Philip
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Son of Sir Maximus; the successful Tory candidate for North Loamshire. "There is a portrait of Mr. Philip Debarry still to be seen at Treby Manor^^ and a very fine bust of him at Rome^^ where he died fifteen years later^^ a convert to Catholocism. His face would have been plain but for the exquisite setting of his hazel eyes^^ which fascinated even the dogs of the household. The other features^^ though slight and irregular^^ were redeemed from triviality by the stamp of gravity and intellectual preoccupation in his face and bearing."

Dublin Core:Title: Debarry^^ Selina
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The younger daughter of Sir Maximus and Lady Debarry^^ "a radiant girl of twenty who had given much time to the harp."

Dublin Core:Title: Dibbs^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A prosperous farmer who holds that if the Radicals are dangerous it is safer to be on their side.

Dublin Core:Title: Filmore^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A surgeon's assistant^^ "whose whiskers and shirt-pin were quite above the average."

Dublin Core:Title: Fortinbras^^ Lord
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mr. Calibut's son-in-law.

Dublin Core:Title: Garstin^^ Peter
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mine owner; Whig candidate for North Loamshire. "Garstin was a harsh and wiry fellow; he seemed to suggest that sour whey^^ which some say was the original meaning of Whig in the Scottish."

Dublin Core:Title: Goffe^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An unsuccessful farmer^^ tenant at Rabbit's End^^ who held that one thing was as mauling as another^^ and that an election was no worse than the sheeprot.

Dublin Core:Title: Gottlib^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A banker who had a run on his bank in 1816.

Dublin Core:Title: Hawkins^^ Brother
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A member of Mr. Lyon's congregation.

Dublin Core:Title: Holt^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Felix Holt's father^^ a quack doctor; an ignorant man who at his death left his widow the receipts for certain worthless medicines as a means of support.

Dublin Core:Title: Holt^^ Felix
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A Radical; a young watchmaker of superior education and strong opinions^^ who devotes his life to the service of the poor and unfortunate. "The minister^^ accustomed to the respectable air of provincial townsmen^^ and especially to the sleek well-clipped gravity of his own male congregation^^ felt a slight shock as his glasses made perfectly clear to him the shaggyheaded^^ large-eyed^^ strong-limbed person of this questionable young man^^ without waistcoat or cravat. . . . he was a peculiar-looking person^^ but not insignificant^^ which was the quality that most hopelessly consigned a man to perdition. He was massively built. The striking points in his face were large clear grey eyes and full lips." "His strong health^^ his renunciation of selfish claims^^ his habitual preoccupation with large thoughts and with purposes in dependent of everyday casualties^^ secured him a fine and even temper^^ free from moodiness or irritability. He was full of longsuffering towards his unwise mother ... he had chosen to fill his days in a way that required the utmost exertion of patience^^ that required those little rill-like out-flowings of goodness which in minds of great energy must be fed from deep sources of thought and passionate devotedness. In this way his energies served to make him gentle; and now^^ in this twenty-sixth year of his life^^ they had ceased to make him angry^^ except in the presence of something that roused his deep indignation." He has been well educated and could live in comfortalbe and "respectable" circumstances^^ but prefers to give up outside refinements to live in poverty among the people whom he wishes to serve. His father had invented some quack medicines upon the sale of which his widowed mother lived comfortably^^ but Felix^^ who knows that the medicines are worthless^^ forces her to give up selling them^^ and provides for her himself. Mrs. Holt^^ who objects strongly to giving up the medicines^^ asks the Reverend Mr. Lyon to reason with Felix^^ and through the minister Felix meets Esther^^ with whom he soon falls in love^^ although at first he sees only surface qualities and faults about which he lectures her. He is interested in the parliamentary campaign in which Harold Transome is the Radical candidate^^ and fears that some of the practices which he has seen will result in trouble. When a serious election riot does occur^^ Felix tries to turn the mob and unintentionally kills a constable. He is tried for manslaughter and sentenced to four years' imprisonment in spite of the testimony of his friends^^ including Esther Lyon^^ who is now known to be the rightful possessor of the Transome estates. Eventually he is pardoned and learns that Esther has given up wealth and position because she returns his love. The two are married and move away from Treby. Some features of Felix Holt were drawn from Gerald Massey.the socialist-poet. (See Collins^^ Studies^^ p. 148; Diet^^ nat. biog.) Another original has been suggested in John Farn^^ of the vicinity of Nuneaton^^ a ribbon weaver and labour agitator with a gift for oratory. See article in Great Thoughts from Master Minds^^ March^^ 1901^^ pp. 369-70. The description of the election riot was suggested by a riot in Nuneaton which George Eliot herself saw when she was thirteen years old. (See Cross^^ George Eliot's Life^^ vol. l^^ pp. 27-9.)

Dublin Core:Title: Holt^^ Mrs. Mary
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mother of Felix; a foolish^^ ignorant^^ and loquacious woman. "She was a tall elderly woman^^ dresssed in black^^ with a lightbrown front and a black band over her forehead . . . Mrs. Holt was not given to tears; she was much sustained by conscious unimpeachableness^^ and by an argumentative tendency which usually checks the too great activity of the lachrymal gland." When Felix makes her give up the sale of the worthless medicines by which she has supported herself^^ she feels deeply injured and never loses an opportunity to talk of this and of her son's obstinacy in giving up what she considers a more genteel position to become a watchmaker.

Dublin Core:Title: Jermyn^^ Miss
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The lawyer's daughter. "She considers herself a judge of what is ladylike^^ and she is vulgarity personified."

Dublin Core:Title: Jermyn^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The lawyer's wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Jermyn^^ Louisa
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The lawyer's second daughter^^ one of Esther Lyon's pupils.

Dublin Core:Title: Jermyn^^ Matthew
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyer; Mrs. Transome's former lover^^ a selfish and unscrupulous man. "He was grey^^ but still remarkably handsome; fat^^ but tall enough to bear that trial to man's dignity. There was as strong a suggestion of toilette about him as if he had been five-and-twenty instead of nearly sixty. He chose always to dress in black and was especially addicted to black satin waistcoats^^ which carried out the general sleekness of his appearance; and this^^ together with his white^^ fat^^ but beautifully-shaped hands^^ which he was in the habit of rubbing gently on his entrance into a room^^ gave him very much the air of a lady's physician." "Jermyn was able and politic enough to have commanded a great deal of success in his life^^ but he could not help being handsome^^ arrogant^^ fond of being heard^^ indisposed to any kind of comradeship^^ amorous and bland towards women^^ cold and selfcontained towards men."  When a handsome and sentimental young man he had been Mrs. Transome's lover and had compromised her. He had used his hold over her to secure his own material advancement^^ and in managing the Transome estate had grown rich and had married and maintained an expensive family. When Harold Transome returns as heir to the Transome estate and discovers Mr. Jermyn's mismanagement and crookedness^^ he quarrels with him^^ and in a public quarrel Mr. Jermyn in forms Harold that he is his father.

Dublin Core:Title: Johnson^^ Mr. John
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Electioneering agent; a vulgar^^ not over-scrupulous man^^ who grows prosperous in the service of Lawyer Jermyn and later turns against him. "A smartly dressed personage on horseback^^ with a  conspicuous expansive shirt-front and figured satin stock. He was a stout man^^ and gave a strong sense of broad-cloth."

Dublin Core:Title: Kemp^^ Brother
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A musical member of Mr. Lyon's congregation^^ with a heavy bass.

Dublin Core:Title: Labron^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lawyer in Treby^^ agent for the Debarrys.

Dublin Core:Title: Lambert^^ Friend
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A member of Mr. Lyon's church.

Dublin Core:Title: Ledru^^ Annette
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A beautiful French woman^^ Esther Lyon's mother^^ who died before the opening of the story. Having married a young Englishman^^ Maurice Christian Bycliffe^^ against the will of her family^^ she had followed him to England^^ where her baby was born and where she learned of her husband's death. After great kindness and devotion from Mr. Lyon she married him^^ but lived for only a few years.

Dublin Core:Title: Lingon^^ Reverend John
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Transom's brother; rector of Little Treby. "The rector of Little Treby had been a favourite in the neighbourhood since the beginning of the century ... He had always been called Jack Lingon^^ or Parson Jack—sometimes^^ in older and less serious days^^ even 'Cockfighting Jack '. He swore a little when the point of a joke seemed to demand it^^ and was fond of wearing a coloured bandana tied loosely over his cravat^^ together with large brown leather leggings; he spoke in a pithy familiar way that people could understand^^ and had none of that frigid mincingness called dignity^^ which some have thought a peculiar clerical disease." Although he had always been a Tory^^ family feeling makes him support his nephew^^ Harold Transome^^ when the latter comes out as a Radical candidate.

Dublin Core:Title: Lyon^^ Esther
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A beautiful and charming girl who gives up the wealth and social position that she might claim in order to marry Felix Holt. "A very delicate scent^^ the faint suggestion of a garden^^ was wafted as she went. He would not observe her^^ but he had a sense of an elastic walk^^ the tread of small feet^^ a long neck^^ and a high crown of shining brown plaits with curls that floated backward — things^^ in short^^ that suggested a fine lady . . . Esther had that excellent thing in woman^^ a soft voice with a clear fluent utterance. Her sauciness was always charming^^ because it was without emphasis^^ and was accompanied with graceful little turns of the head." "She had one of those exceptional organizations which are quick and sensitive without being in the least morbid ; she was alive to the finest shades of manner^^ to the nicest distinctions of tone and accent . . . Her own pretty instep^^ clad in a silk stocking^^ her little heel^^ just rising from a kid slipper^^ her irreproachable nails and delicate wrist^^ were the objects of delighted consciousness to her; and she felt that it was her superiority which made her unable to use without disgust any but the finest cambric handkerchiefs and freshest gloves. Her money all went in the gratification of these nice tastes^^ and she saved nothing from her earnings . . . she hated all meanness^^ would empty her purse impulsively on some sudden appeal to her pity^^ and if she found out that her father had a want she would supply it with some pretty device of a surprise." She had been brought up as the daughter of Rufus Lyon^^ the Independent minister^^ and while fond of her father has little sympathy with his simple tastes and life. Through her father she meets Felix Holt. and while at first repelled by his surface roughness^^ soon becomes interested in him and in the lectures that he gives her. Fearing that she may hear the story from someone else^^ Rufus Lyon tells her that he is not her real father^^ and that she is the daughter of Maurice Christian Bycliffe. She is much touched by his story of his devotion and marriage to her mother^^ and gains a different appreciation of his life and character. Later^^ after she learns that she is the rightful owner of the Transome estates^^ she goes to Transome Court to visit Mrs. Transome^^ and there is courted by Harold Transome. What she sees at Transome Court shows her that wealth does not necessarily bring happiness^^ and as Felix Holt's trial for manslaughter has opened her eyes to the strength of her real feeling for him^^ she gives up her claim to the estate to marry Felix. While George Eliot's portrait of Esther Lyon is not autobiographic to anything like the same extent as that of the character of Maggie Tulliver (in Mill on the Floss)^^ there are some things in it--the fastidiousness^^ niceness about dress^^ etc.-for which the author's own tastes and habits supplied the original. (See Parkinson^^ Scenes from the George Eliot Country^^ p. 85; Timmins^^ History of Warwickshire^^ p. 151.)

Dublin Core:Title: Lyon^^ Rev. Rufus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The ardent minister of the Independent Chapel in Treby Magna^^ and Esther Lyon's reputed father^^ a man of many lovable oddities and much nobility of character. "He was walking about now^^ with his hands clasped behind him^^ an attitude in which his body seemed to bear about the same proportion to his head as the lower part of a stone Hermes bears to the carven image that crowns it. His face looked old and worn^^ yet the curtain of hair that fell from his bald crown and hung about his neck retained much of its original auburn tint^^ and his large^^ brown^^ short-sighted eyes were still clear and bright. At the first glance^^ every one thought him a very odd-looking rusty old man; the free-school boys often hooted after him and called him "Revelations"; and to many respectable church people old Lyon's little legs and large head seemed to make Dissent additionally preposterous. But he was too shortsighted to notice those who tittered at him-too absent from the world of small facts and petty impulses in which titterers live." "Once in his life he had been blinded^^ deafened^^ hurried along by rebellious impulse ; he had gone astray after his own desires^^ and had let the fire die out on the altar ; and as the true penitent^^ hating his self-besotted error^^ asks from all coming life duty instead of joy^^ and service instead of ease^^ so Rufus was perpetually on the watch lest he should ever again postpone to some private affection a great public opportunity which to him was equivalent to a command." Twenty-two years before the opening of the story Rufus Lyon was an eloquent and successful minister of a large Independent Chapel^^ when Annette Ledru came suddenly into his life. The death of her husband^^ Maurice Christian Bycliffe^^ had left her penniless in a strange land^^ and Mr. Lyon took her and her baby into his home^^ in spite of the criticism of his congregation^^ fell deeply in love with her^^ and gave up his high calling to watch over her and her child. After a time the grateful Annette married him and when she died^^ three years later^^ he returned to the ministry^^ and brought up the baby^^ Esther^^ as his own daughter. At the opening of the story he is leading^^ in humble surroundings^^ a life of wrapt absorption in his work and loving devotion to Esther^^ who still believes herself his daughter. When events make him believe that she should no longer be kept in ignorance of her parentage he tells her the full story and leaves her free to decide whether or not she will claim the inheritance and rank to which she is apparently entitled. The original of Rufus Lyon was the Reverend Francis Franklin^^ a Baptist minister^^ who for fifty-four years^^ from 1799 until his death in 1852^^ was pastor of the Cow Lane Chapel^^ in Coventry. Mr. Franklin was the father of the Misses Franklin^^ whose school in Coventry George Eliot attended^^ and the character of Rufus Lyon is said by those who remembered him^^ to be a faithful portrait. (See Cross^^ George Eliot's Life^^ vol. 1^^ pp. 24-5; Negri^^ George Eliot^^ vol. 2^^ p. 62; also article in Our Times^^ June^^ 1881.)

Dublin Core:Title: Methurst^^ Lady Alicia
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An acquaintance of Lady Debarry's.

Dublin Core:Title: Muscat^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An influential member of Mr. Lyon's congregation.

Dublin Core:Title: Muscat^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Wife of the above^^ "who had once been a beauty and was as nice in her millinery as any Trebian lady belonging to the Establishment."

Dublin Core:Title: Muscat^^ Young
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Son of Mr. and Mrs. Muscat; an unsuccessful admirer of Esther Lyon's.

Dublin Core:Title: Nolan^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Wife of the retired merchant; formerly Miss Pendrell.

Dublin Core:Title: Nolan^^ Baruch
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A retired London hosier believed to understand politics; a wealthy and esteemed inhabitant of Treby^^ whose Hebrew extraction is ignored. "A wiry old gentleman past seventy^^ whose square tight forehead^^ with its rigid hedge of grey hair^^ whose bushy eyebrows^^ sharp dark eyes^^ and remarkable hooked nose^^ gave a handsome distinction to his face in the midst of rural physiognomies."

Dublin Core:Title: Nuttwood^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Dissenter and deacon; a grocer in Treby Magna.

Dublin Core:Title: Nuttwood^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The grocer's wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Patch^^ Ned
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Pedlar.

Dublin Core:Title: Pendrell^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Banker in Treby Magna.

Dublin Core:Title: Pendrell^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The banker's wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Pink^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Saddler^^ whose shop is the centre of gossip in Treby Magna. "Mr. Pink professed a deepdyed Toryism; but he regarded all fault-finding as Radical and somewhat impious^^ as disturbing to trade^^ and likely to offend the gentry or the servants through whom their harness was ordered.... It was only the 'Papists' who lived far enough off to be spoken of uncivilly."

Dublin Core:Title: Prowd^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Watchmaker in Treby Magna.

Dublin Core:Title: Putty^^ James
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A successful electioneering agent^^ admired by Mr. Johnson.

Dublin Core:Title: Revising Barrister^^ The
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An official who comes to Treby Magna before the Parliamentary election.

Dublin Core:Title: Rose^^ Mrs.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The farmer's wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Rose^^ Mr. Timothy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: "A gentleman farmer from leek Malton^^ against whose independent position nature had provided the safeguard of a spontaneous servility."

Dublin Core:Title: Salt^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Wool-factor^^ "who only spoke when there was a good opportunity of contradicting."

Dublin Core:Title: Sampson^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Driver of the North Loamshire coach.

Dublin Core:Title: Scales^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Sir Maximus Debarry's house steward and head butler^^ "a man most solicitous about his boots^^ wrist-bands^^ the roll of his whiskers^^ and other attributes of a gentleman."

Dublin Core:Title: Sherlock^^ Rev. Theodore^^ B.A.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Curate in Treby Magna; a bashful young man of good birth. The rector assigns to him the task of holding a public debate with Mr. Lyon^^ but on the day of the debate his timidity over comes him and he leaves the town.

Dublin Core:Title: Sims^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Auctioneer in Treby Magna.

Dublin Core:Title: Sircome^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An eminent miller.

Dublin Core:Title: Sleck^^ Old
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Miner at Sproxton.

Dublin Core:Title: Spratt^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The hated manager of the Sproxton colliery. On election day he falls into the hands of the Treby mob and is rescued from death by Felix Holt^^ who^^ while apparently sym pathizing with the rioters^^ induces them to leave Spratt tied to a finger-post.

Dublin Core:Title: Tiliot^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Rich spirit merchant in Treby Magna^^ whose church views become higher and higher as his gin becomes famous.

Dublin Core:Title: Tiliot^^ Mrs. Mary
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The spirit merchant's wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Transome^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Owner of Transome Court; a feeble-minded paralytic who lives in fear of his handsome^^ dominating wife.

Dublin Core:Title: Transome^^ Mrs. Arabella
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Harold Transome's mother; a handsome^^ imperious^^ disappointed woman whose age is embittered by the unhappy consequences of a sin of her young married days. "Her figure was slim and finely formed^^ though she was between fifty and sixty. She was a tall^^ proud-looking woman^^ with abundant grey hair^^ dark eyes and eyebrows^^ and a somewhat eaglelike^^ yet not unfeminine^^ face. Her tight-fitting black dress was much worn; the fine lace of her cuffs and collar^^ and of the small veil which fell backwards over her high comb^^ was visibly mended; but rare jewels flashed on her hands^^ which lay on her folded black-clad arms^^ like finely cut onyx cameos ... " "Crosses^^ mortifications^^ money cares^^ conscious blameworthiness^^ had changed the aspect of the world for her; there was anxiety in the morning sunlight ; there was unkind triumph or disapproving pity in the glances of greeting neighbours . . . Mrs. Transome^^ whose imperious will had availed little to ward off the great evils of her life^^ found the opiate for her discontent in the exertion of her will about smaller things. She was not cruel^^ and could not enjoy thoroughly what I she called the old woman's pleasure of tormenting; but she liked every little sign of power her lot had left her. She liked that a tenant should stand bareheaded below her as she eat on horseback. She liked to insist that work done without her orders should be undone from beginning to end ... a woman's keen sensibility and dread ... lay screened behind all her petty habits and narrow notions." As a proud young beauty of good family but little money^^ she had made a loveless marriage with the feeble Mr. Transome. Feeling no fondnees for either her husband or her half-idiot eldest son^^ she had responded to the attentions of the handsome young lawyer^^ Jermyn^^ and later had centred all her love and pride in her second son^^ Harold^^ a healthy handsome boy. Her dominating nature makes her enjoy managing the estate in place of her feeble husband^^ but lawsuits and the charges which the unscrupulous Jermyn has fastened on the estate have greatly reduced the income. On the death of her disreputable eldest son she eagerly anticipates Harold's return from the East^^ where he has gone to make his fortune^^ and expects to find in his devotion a solace for all her dissatisfactions. She is bitterly disappointed when^^ instead of this devotion^^ he gives her merely a good-humoured^^ condescending affection; feels the loss of authority when he does not defer to her about the management of the estate; and watches with helpless dread the growing antagonism between him and Jermyn. Finally^^ when Jermyn^^ in a public quarrel^^ tells Harold that he is his father^^ her unhappy secret is revealed to her son. After his first reaction to this shock^^ Harold treats her with gentleness^^ and takes her abroad^^ away from the associations of Transome Court.

Dublin Core:Title: Transome^^ Lady Betty
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A beauty whom Sir Peter Lely painted.

Dublin Core:Title: Transome^^ Durfey
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The vicious and imbecile son of the Transomes^^ whose death makes his younger brother^^ Harold^^ the heir to the estate.

Dublin Core:Title: Transome^^ Harold
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Mrs. Transome's younger son; a handsome^^ agreeable and selfish^^ but not dishonourable young man. "This determined aiming at something not easy but clearly possible marked the direction in which Harold's nature was strong; he had the energetic will and muscle^^ the self-confidence^^ the quick perception^^ and the narrow imagination which make what is admiringly called the practical mind . . . He was addicted at once to rebellion and to conformity^^ and only an intimate personal knowledge could enable any one to predict where his conformity would begin . . . In fact^^ Harold Transome was a clever^^ frank^^ good-natured egoist; not stringently consistent^^ but without any disposition to falsity; proud^^ but with a pride that was moulded in an individual rather than an hereditary form; unspeculative^^ unsentimental^^ unsympathetic; fond of sensual pleasures^^ but disinclined to all vice^^ and ttached as a healthy^^ clear sighted person^^ to all conventional morality^^ construed with a certain freedom." In his youth he had gone to the East^^ where he married a Greek woman^^ originally a slave^^ and made a fortune. A widower of thirty-four^^ he returns to England when his brother's death makes him the heir to the Transome estates. Breaking with the family traditions of Toryism^^ he stands for Parliament as a Radical^^ and is defeated after an exciting campaign and election. In looking into the estate business management^^ he finds that Mr. Jermyn^^ the family lawyer^^ has taken advantage of his position to his own profit^^ and starts legal proceedings against him. When he learns that Esther Lyon is the rightful owner of the estate he becomes genuinely interested in her^^ wants to marry her^^ but fails to win her love. In a public quarrel Mr. Jermyn tells Harold that he^^ Jermyn^^ is his father^^ and^^ as a result Harold and his mother leave England for a time.

Dublin Core:Title: Transome^^ Harry
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Harold Transome's little son; a black-eyed^^ tyrannical child of three.

Dublin Core:Title: Transome^^ John Justus
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The ancestor of the Transomes^^ who^^ in 1729^^ entailed the estates on his son^^ Thomas^^ and his heirs-males^^ with remainder to the Bycliffes in fee.

Dublin Core:Title: Transome^^ Thomas
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: The prodigal son of John Justus Transome^^ who sold his own and his descendants' right to a cousin named Durfey.

Dublin Core:Title: Trounsem^^ or Transome^^ Tommy
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Bill-sticker; an old drunkard. Unknown to himself^^ he is the last descendant of the Thomas Transome who sold his and his descendants' rights in the Tran some estate to the Durfeys. His death in the election riot makes Esther Lyon^^ the descendant of the Bycliffes^^ the legal owner of the estate.

Dublin Core:Title: Truncheon^^ Dr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A London physician.

Dublin Core:Title: Tudge^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Job's grandfather; a stone-breaker.

Dublin Core:Title: Tudge^^ Job
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A small protege of Felix Holt's^^ to whom Mrs. Holt is very kind. "Job was a small fellow about five^^ with a germinal nose^^ large round blue eyes^^ and red hair that curled close to his head like the wool on the back of an infantine lamb."

Dublin Core:Title: Wace^^ Mr.
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Rich brewer in Treby Magna^^ a jolly^^ open-handed man.

Dublin Core:Title: Whitefield^^ George^^ Bust of
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: An ornament of Mr. Lyon's study^^ which is covered with green gauze because Esther can not bear its squint. George Whitefield (1714-70). Just such a bust of Whitefield stood in the staircase window of the Misses Franklin's school in Coventry where George Eliot was a pupil. Mr. Franklin was the original of Rufus Lyon. (See article in Our Times^^ June^^ 1881.) This bust still is in existence^^ and is now the property of Mr. Bernard Franklin^^ a grandson of Francis Franklin.

Dublin Core:Title: Wyvern^^ Lady
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Wife of Lord Wyvern.

Dublin Core:Title: Wyvern^^ Lord
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: One of the Transomes' neighbours.

Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Lord Brackenshaw's agent.

Dublin Core:Title: Blenny
Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: A former tenant of Offendene.

Dublin Core:Subject: Character Name
Dublin Core:Description: Blacksmith^^ fond of his trade.

Dublin Core:Subject: Pet Name

Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Baden-Baden (Real)^^German spa. A beautifully situated watering-place at the entrance to the Black Forest.

Dublin Core:Description: Blackfriars Bridge (Real)^^A bridge over the Thames.

Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Brompton (Real)^^The part of London in which Mordecai Cohen and his sister live after they find each other. A section in the west part of London^^ including the South Kensington Museums.

Dublin Core:Title: Chelsea (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Chelsea (Real)^^Part of London where the Meyricks life. A residential part of London on the north bank of the Thames. George Eliot herself dwelt there during the last few weeks of her life.

Dublin Core:Title: Crystal Palace^^ London (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Crystal Palace^^ London (Real)^^The place where Ezra Cohen and his mother once saw the Emperor and Empress. The Crystal Palace^^ at Sydenham^^ 6 miles south of London Bridge^^ is a huge exhibition hall^^ a reconstruction of the one designed by Sir Joseph Paxton for the Exhibition of 1851^^ in Hyde Park. Napoleon III and Eugenie visited the Crystal Palace of Sydenham in 1855.

Dublin Core:Title: Dover (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Dover (Real)^^An English port on the strait of Dover^^ a principal part for the packet service to the Continent.

Dublin Core:Title: Dresden (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Dresden (Real)^^A German city^^ capital of Saxony.

Dublin Core:Title: Frankfort (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Frankfort (Real)^^The German city where Daniel Deronda attends services in the old synagogue of the Orthodox Jews and is seen by his grandfather's friend Joseph Kalonymos. Frankfort-am-Main^^ a German city with an important Jewish population^^ including a group of ultra-Orthodox Jews.

Dublin Core:Title: Gottingen (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Gottingen (Real)^^One of the places where Mordecai Cohen had studied. A university town in Hanover^^ Germany.

Dublin Core:Title: Grosvenor Place (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Grosvenor Place (Real)^^Street in London where the Klesmers live. Grosvenor Place^^ a fine residence street just west of Buckingham Palace Gardens.

Dublin Core:Title: Grosvenor Square (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Grosvenor Square (Real)^^The square in London where the Grandcourts live. One of the most fashionable and aristocratic squares in London^^ a little east of Hyde Park.

Dublin Core:Title: Hamburg (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Hamburg (Real)^^City where Mirah Cohen had once lived and where her brother Mordecai had studied. The free city of Hamburg^^ on the Elbe^^ in Germany.

Dublin Core:Title: Holborn (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Holborn (Real)^^A street in London near which the Cohens' pawnshop is located.

Dublin Core:Title: Judengabbe (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Judengabbe (Real)^^A street in Frankfort which Daniel Deronda explores.

Dublin Core:Title: Kew Bridge (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Kew Bridge (Real)^^The bridge over the Thames^^ under which Daniel Deronda rows just before he first sees Mirah Cohen.

Dublin Core:Title: Kew Gardens (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Kew Gardens (Real)^^The place near which Daniel Deronda rescues Mirah Cohen when she is attempting to drown herself in the Thames. Kew Gardnes^^ the Royal Botanic Gardens^^ on the Thames^^ about sixteen miles from London.

Dublin Core:Title: Knightsbridge (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Knightsbridge (Real)^^A street in London out of which Mirah Cohen has just turned when she sees her father following her.

Dublin Core:Title: Lambeth (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Lambeth (Real)^^The part of London where Mirah Cohen had lived with her mother. A metropolitan borough of London^^ on the south bank of the Thames.

Dublin Core:Title: Mainz (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Mainz (Real)^^The city in Germany where Joseph Kalonymos' banking establishment is located; Daniel Deronda goes there to get his grandfather's papers from Kalonymos. Mainz (or Mayance)^^ on the Rhine just below the confluence of the Main and the Rhine.

Dublin Core:Title: Marble Arch (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Marble Arch (Real)^^Spot near which Mirah Cohen first sees her father when he returns to London. The Marble Arch^^ a triumphal arch^^ erected in 1828 in front of Buckingham Palace and removed about 1850 to its present site at the northeast corner of Hyde Park.

Dublin Core:Title: Marseilles (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Marseilles (Real)^^French Mediterranean port from which the Grandcourts start on their yachting trip.

Dublin Core:Title: National Gallery^^ London (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: National Gallery^^ London (Real)^^One of the places in which Mordecai Cohen frequently lingers^^ hoping to fnd in the portraits a type of a great Jewish leader.

Dublin Core:Title: Park Lane (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Park Lane (Real)^^The street in London where Sir Hugo Mallinger lives.

Dublin Core:Title: Pesth (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Pesth (Real)^^One of the cities where Mirah Cohen and her father^^ Lapidoth^^ had been. Pesth^^ now part of Budapest^^ the capital of Hungary (formed by the union of Buda and Pesth in 1873)^^ was at the time of Daniel Deronda a separate city.

Dublin Core:Title: Putney (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Putney (Real)^^Place on the Thames where Daniel Deronda had a boat. A village on the Thames six miles from London.

Dublin Core:Title: Rabbinische Schule (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Rabbinische Schule (Real)^^The synagogue of the orthodox Jews in Frankfort where Daniel Deronda attends a service and is seen by his grandfather's old friend^^ Joseph Kalonymos. The Synagogue Beth Tefillah Jeschurun^^ in the Schutzenstrasse^^ built by the Israelitische Religionsgesellschaft in 1853^^ was^^ at the time of Daniel Deronda (1866)^^ the only large synagogue of the orthodox Jews in Frankfort.

Dublin Core:Title: Richmond Bridge (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Richmond Bridge (Real)^^Bridge over the Thames under which Daniel Deronda rows shortly before he rescues Mirah Cohen from drowning.

Dublin Core:Title: Rotten Row (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Rotten Row (Real)^^Gwendolen^^ riding with Grandcourt in Rotten Row^^ sees Mrs. Glasher watching her. Rotten Row^^ the track for riders on the south side of Hyde Park^^ extending from Hyde Park corner to Kensington. Probably so called after the rotten soil of which it is composed^^ though other etymologies have been suggested.

Dublin Core:Title: Schuster Strasse (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Schuster Strasse (Real)^^The street in Mainz^^ where Joseph Kalonymos' banking house is located. This is the Schuster Gasse.

Dublin Core:Title: Spezia (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Spezia (Real)^^An important maritime town of Italy^^ on the Bay of Spezia^^ fifty miles southeast of Genoa.

Dublin Core:Title: Thames (Real)
Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Thames (Real)^^The river on which Daniel Deronda frequently rows^^ and from which he rescues Mirah Cohen when she tries to drown herself. The Thames^^ which is the most important river in England^^ divides London in two portions. A stretch of the river above London extending to Hampton Court is a favourite place for boating excursions.

Dublin Core:Subject: Real Place
Dublin Core:Description: Theatre Francais^^ Paris (Real)^^The French national theatre^^ founded 1681^^ under the name Comedie francaise; the name Theatre francais dates from about 1791.

Dublin Core:Description: Gadsmere^^Grandcourt's place in a coal mining district where Mrs. Glasher and her children live for several years. In his will he leaves it to Gwendolen as her place of residence. "Imagine a rambling^^ patchy house^^ the best part built of grey stone^^ and red-tiled^^ a round tower jutting at one of the corners^^ the mellow darkness of its conical roof surmounted by a weather-cock making an agree able object either amidst the gleams and greenth of summer or the low-hanging clouds and snowy branches of winter; the ground shady with spreading trees: a great cedar flourishing on one side^^ backward some Scotch firs on a broken bank where the roots hung naked^^ and beyond^^ a rookery: on the other side a pool overhung with bushes^^ where the water-fowl fluttered and screamed: all around^^ a vast meadow which might be called a park^^ bordered by an old plantation and guarded by stone lodges which looked like little prisons. Outside the gate the country^^ once entirely rural and lovely^^ now black with coal-mines."

Dublin Core:Title: Green Arbour

But inside and outside it was what no beholder could suppose to be inhabited by retired tradespeople."

Dublin Core:Title: Turvey

Dublin Core:Title: "Clerical Gazette"
Dublin Core:Subject: Item
